TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members who watch the news would have seen the recent bushfire tragedy in south-east Queensland vividly portrayed. Most of the bushfires were situated in the federal electorate of Fisher. At times like this when great adversity is faced it is wonderful to see communities, councils, emergency services and people generally pulling together and working together to assist those who are having difficult times.

PARA.TAB: The tragedy could have been infinitely worse had these facilities and this cooperation not existed. Had the wind not changed, a major tragedy could have become a monumental tragedy. Thousands of people were evacuated from their homes at Bribie Island, Beerwah and elsewhere. If it were not for the commonsense of those in charge, the situation could have been terrible indeed.

I have asked the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on notice whether his attention has been drawn to this bushfire tragedy which saw evacuations, at least 13 homes lost and a declaration of a state of emergency. I have also drawn his attention to the danger of more bushfires occurring and the resultant potential catastrophe. I have asked whether he or a representative would visit the affected areas to inspect the damage. I have also asked the government to consider providing assistance to those who have been afflicted as a result of the bushfires. I have not yet heard from the Prime Minister, but I am hoping the government will favourably consider the difficulties being experienced by a very large number of people in south-east Queensland.

It is interesting to note that during times of great tragedy we often find great bravery. We have a large number of firemen, some of whom are volunteers and some of whom are members of the fire service. Fortunately, at this stage there has not been any loss of life in the Queensland bushfires. I would also like to pay tribute to the members of the Palmwoods Volunteer Fire Brigade for their bravery and for what they achieved without regard to the danger posed to their own lives.

In particular, I will mention one of the volunteers, Clive Gauldie, who was responsible for saving the life of one of his colleagues, Neil Dingwall, who had joined the fire brigade less than 24 hours earlier. According to a local newspaper article, a Palmwoods volunteer firefighter was running for his life through a fireball on Tuesday when he stopped to take a burning colleague by the hand and lead him from the inferno. That firefighter was Clive Gauldie.

During times of war and civil tragedy we find great bravery. The fact that Neil Dingwall's life was saved is a great tribute to the bravery of Clive Gauldie and others who risk their lives in their jobs. It should be recognised that more services need to be provided to rural brigades to enable them to fight bushfires.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—Mr Speaker, I require that the debate be extended.
—The debate may continue until 6.10 p.m.

—I rise to respond to the comments that were made by the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) in relation to the sad death of Michael Vanstone, who was a friend of his and a friend of mine. At one time in his career Michael Vanstone was a research officer with the committee office in the parliament. I understand from staff here that he was very highly regarded and a free spirit. The last comment that was made to me is one that I can certainly endorse. He was a very decent man and his passing is of great sadness to all of those who knew him and knew of him.

PARA.TAB: As the member for Warringah said, Michael Vanstone was the editor of the Sydney Review and had earlier worked as the associate editor of the Adelaide Review. The editor of the Adelaide Review is Christopher Pearson, who is also a friend of mine. I understand that Michael Vanstone, on his deathbed, actually sought an assurance from Christopher Pearson that he would do everything in his power to ensure that the Sydney Review, much beloved by Michael Vanstone, would not be allowed to die. Christopher Pearson, as I understand it, gave him that assurance.

However, the situation in Adelaide is that the Murdoch press has chosen to launch a monthly arts publication quite specifically—I do not think this could be denied—targeted at removing the one tiny piece of print competition it has in Adelaide. To recap what the member for Warringah said, in Adelaide the Murdoch press owns the Advertiser daily and the Advertiser distributed on Saturday, and the Sunday Mail. It owns the only non-free weekly publication and it owns all of the publications which are known as the suburban free weeklies. So in Adelaide there is almost a monopoly. The Adelaide Review is the only piece of print journalism that is available. The Adelaide Advertiser has chosen to launch a monthly arts magazine, which will be, as we understand it, an insert to the Advertiser. For 200,000 copies, advertisers will only have to pay 1.2 times the rate charged by the Adelaide Review. Any student studying the trade practices laws of this country could see that this is an effective and targeted effort to deny the Adelaide Review advertising revenue and thus drive it out of business.

The Murdoch press-News Ltd management should think long and hard about this strategy. I do not think it is a strategy which will serve its corporate interests nationally. Many people will be extremely unhappy about its attempt to drive the Adelaide Review out of business. I agree with comments that were made by the member for Warringah. Normally competition is a good thing; if one can do better then so be it. However, in the area of the media I think a very different set of principles needs to apply.

I do not want to delay the House any further, but I simply caution Murdoch press-News Ltd to think long and hard about this strategy. I think it is a wrong-headed strategy and one that will not serve it well. If it is successful in driving the Adelaide Review out of business, it is certainly not a strategy that will serve the people of Adelaide. I hope that will not happen and I am confident that the people who have supported the Adelaide Review in the past will show loyalty to it. I sincerely hope that the memory of Michael Vanstone continues on in the Adelaide Review and the Sydney Review.

RDI.ITEM.TITLE: Locks on Windows in Parliament House

TALK.START.PARA: asked Mr Speaker, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: Do some windows in Parliament House have locks fitted; if so, (a) how many, (b) what was the total cost of the locks, (c) was Parliament House designed not to allow windows to open and (d) why were the locks fitted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Mr Speaker

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a)It is estimated that there are some 2486 locks fitted to windows in rooms, corridors and public spaces.
(b)Unavailable. Locks were not separately costed in construction contracts.

(c)Yes. The ability to allow windows to be opened at will is determined at the design stage. In Parliament House the opening of windows would unbalance the airconditioning causing discomfort to adjacent occupants by reducing their air flow. Temperature control would also be adversely affected. Substantial cost in trying to rebalance the airconditioning and significant additional energy consumption would be incurred if the original design intent to keep windows closed was altered.
(d)The locks were fitted to maintain security on windows that on occasions may need to be opened for emergency or maintenance related access.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill 1994 is a very important bill because it covers a wide range of issues on where government enterprises are going. This bill is particularly about Australia Post, but it can be connected with a lot of other government enterprises that are looking at privatisation, deregulation, corporatisation—call it what you will—and how we balance the various interests and opinions in that. It is worth looking firstly at the performance of Australia Post over recent years.

PARA.TAB: The corporation's 1992-93 annual report confirmed that Australia Post has come a long way in productivity and efficiency: labour productivity in that year increased a record 5.1 per cent and there was a record low level of time lost per full-time employee due to industrial disputation. More than 92 per cent of letters were delivered on time. Australia Post also achieved a $249.4 million profit, which was a record. The return on assets was 14.8 per cent, after including the community service obligations, and there was a $62 million dividend to the government. I think this shows that Australia Post has come a long way in becoming efficient and in delivering a very good service to all Australians. This bill is about where Australia Post goes in the future.

However, there is a conflict in the obligations of Australia Post. On the one hand, the act requires that Australia Post operate commercially to give a profit to the government and be efficient. On the other hand, Australia Post is required to deliver service obligations, so-called community service obligations, some of which, by definition, are unprofitable. That provides a conflict for the management of Australia Post as to where it puts the balance. I think it is worth looking at the issues of where the public interest lies and how we get to what the public interest is.

The basic community service obligation of Australia Post at present is to provide a uniform letter service at a uniform rate on an equitable basis for Australians. Most of the public would not view that community service obligation as that narrow. It is worth noting that that community service requirement in the act is interpreted by Australia Post management, and it is interpreted by various standards that Australia Post applies to its business.

Its delivery standards say: first business day delivery within metropolitan areas of capital cities or within the same cities or town environments; second business day delivery between a metropolitan area and country locations within the same state; second business day delivery between country areas of the same state; second day delivery between metropolitan areas of different capital cities; third business day delivery between metropolitan areas of capital cities and country locations in other states; and fourth business day delivery between country areas in different states.

In deciding that delivery frequency, Australia Post also arrived at a series of cost scales that are based on the amount that it costs to deliver a letter to a metropolitan delivery point. The method of costing that is based on what is called the urban base rate, which is currently $93 per annum. As defined by Australia Post, the cost delivery scales for roadside delivery are as follows. If the cost is up two UBRs, urban based rates, people get five deliveries per week; between two and three, they get three deliveries per week; between three and eight, two per week; between eight and 13, one per week. That is the definition of how the community service obligation of a standard letter service is interpreted by Australia Post.

Continuing on with that, it is noticeable that, at the bottom end of the scale in remote country areas, the cost is greater and the return is probably unprofitable in some areas. It is certainly unprofitable in many areas. The pressure on the management of Australia Post is to balance that with the community service obligation. As I see it, there is continuing pressure on community service obligations. That is reflected in the Hilmer report, where Professor Hilmer says that if governments choose to restrict consumer ability to choose among rival suppliers—in other words, if we choose not to implement deregulation continually, or to a great extent—it should be demonstrated why this is necessary from the public interest point of view. Hilmer put a bias against the public interest in that case because he said that it must be demonstrated to be in the public interest. Dealing with Australia Post and community service obligations, I would rather say that it should be demonstrated that it is in the public interest to deregulate rather than the other way around.

In respect of the CSOs, the community service obligations, I noticed an amendment which, in part, goes to the focus of CSOs. The amendment is about an additional service for the eight to 13 urban based rates—the multiple rate to 13—which receive one per week. I have had a look at the speeches of previous opposition members. The amendment really does not deal with the issues of substance. The issues of substance are as follows: how much pressure is put on Australia Post to return dividends; and how much deregulation is allowed into Australia Post, which again puts pressure on its profit performance and its ability to deliver CSOs. There is also the question of the right way to fund CSOs—whether through the cross-subsidy, as occurs at present, or whether, as suggested by Hilmer and I think the IC report, by a separate budgetary item. Another issue is the methodology used in costing those community service obligations. All those issues are going to affect the extent and the breadth of how CSOs are delivered.

Those are very important points that the government must consider as we progress towards the economic point of view that deregulation, almost in all circumstances, is a good thing and in the public interest. Hilmer seems to put forward the idea in his report that the public interest is equivalent to economic efficiency goals. I dispute that in some cases, particularly for rural Australia.

The question to be answered is: how do we cost CSOs? The present method of costing is by the long-term avoidable cost, because that is the allowance the government makes in determining what the profit performance of Australia Post should be. If the costing of the CSOs is low, the allowance made to the profit performance of Australia Post is then smaller than it should be. The long-term avoidable cost is the saving that can be made at the margin if the service is not provided. Using that prescribed methodology, the cost of CSOs in 1992-93 was $46 million.

There are more realistic ways of costing CSOs. The present costing meets the needs or criteria of economists in the Treasury. It produces results which are not realistic in ordinary commercial terms. A more appropriate way of measuring the real CSOs of Australia Post would be to estimate the cash cost of the benefits provided by virtue of government ownership to various groups in the community on a non-commercial basis. If an assessment of the CSOs were made on that alternative basis for 1992-93, it would indicate the following estimated costs: retail network losses for non-reserved services necessarily incurred to provide universal access to postal facilities, $30 million; reserved services cross-subsidy, $122 million; registered publication losses, $11 million; and heritage property costs, which are not included at all, $20 million. That would give a total of $183 million.

Australia Post is allowed by the government around $50 million. It is fairly obvious that Australia Post would acknowledge a more realistic cost of $183 million, and it is not getting allowance for that. It would be a natural reaction for Australia Post management to try to push down its CSO costs.

Apart from that, there are other issues that are affecting Australia Post in providing CSOs, sometimes in a more implicit way. Australia Post needs to earn a commercial rate of return on its assets. It needs to maintain the extent of the Commonwealth's equity in Australia Post and the expectation of the Commonwealth that Australia Post will return a dividend. It needs to maintain Australia Post's financial viability and it needs to consider the cost of the CSOs, which I have just mentioned, and other commercial matters.

In addition, Australia Post is now required to make capital repayments to the Commonwealth. Those payments make Australia Post borrow to a level that is seen as a normal debt to equity ratio of a commercial enterprise. Last year $200 million was requested as a first-off capital repayment. There are opinions that that should be increased until the debt to equity ratio reaches a ratio of one to two.

Under those pressures, and in light of the IC report and the Hilmer report, it is quite clear to me that the conflict between the need to return a profit and the obligation to deliver the CSOs is biased in favour of returning that commercial profit. That situation will continue to exist. It will be exacerbated by further deregulation of Australia Post. I support this bill because I believe the deregulation contained in it does not upset the balance between the deliveries of the CSOs and the ability of Australia Post to act commercially and efficiently. In fact, I believe it will increase that ability.

I have already spoken about some of the substantive issues in terms of the opposition's proposed amendments. The opposition has taken an extremely narrow view of this. It has said, `Let's have two deliveries per week in those areas that are currently only getting one per week.' What about people who are now receiving two per week? Should they get three? What about those who are now getting two to three? Should they get four? What about those who are getting up to two? Should they get more? Should the idea of CSOs be broadened to include other services that are not now included in the requirements for CSOs? They are the questions that need to be asked.

Some people in remote and isolated Australia have great difficulty receiving mail services on a regular basis. What about them? Their situation needs attention too. It has to start with how CSOs are delivered and funded—for example, whether they are funded by a cross-subsidy or by a separate budgetary item.

The best way to fund CSOs in order to maintain or increase them is through cross-subsidy. If they were made a separate budgetary item there would continually be pressure to reduce them. The problem of the methodology of costing would also come in. Should the budgetary item be $50 million, in the way that CSOs are costed now, or should it be the real cost, which is $183 million? Treasury would not agree to that. If it were a separate budgetary item at $50 million, we would not get the delivery of the current service, because it costs more.

The opposition needs to answer some questions on this issue for the public good. For example, what is its intention with Australia Post? The other day the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) said that he will boost infrastructure development—and I applaud that—with money raised through privatisation. It is my view that a full privatisation of Australia Post would result in CSOs having to be funded through a separate budgetary item, which would mean that we would not get the delivery of CSOs as they are now. Further, the government has instituted a method by which public and parliamentary input can be made to the way in which CSOs are interpreted. As I have said in the past, the standards at the present time are set by Australia Post management.

Next year there will be a public inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. We have decided that that will be done each term, and it will be about what the public expects from the delivery of CSOs. Its findings will be reported to the government and the government will then need to respond to that report. The committee, of course, is a cross-parliamentary committee, and I am sure the rural members of the opposition will be very interested in it. It is absolutely essential that interested rural people give evidence to it and make well heard their point of view about what they see as the community service obligation of Australia Post, which is not what is presently there.

Both the Hilmer and the Industry Commission reports, and economic thought generally, have pushed the bias in these issues away from the public interest and towards purely economic interests. We need to bring that back a little. If we can do that through the House of Representatives committee—which will give the people of Australia and the members of parliament an ability to have an input into what these standards are—we will see a far better interpretation of what the act says about CSOs.

Finally, I applaud Australia Post and the workers of Australia Post for the way they have gone about their business in the last few years and increased their efficiency and standards of delivery greatly. I call again on future speakers for the opposition to state exactly whether their policy is to fully privatise or to fully regulate Australia Post.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to participate in this debate and to have the opportunity to follow my friend the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) in his deliberations on the Australia Postal Corporation Amendment Bill. I hope the member for Page was appropriately touched by the crowded opposition benches that his speech in the Main Committee produced. I have to say that I am less than flattered by discovering, now that an opposition member rises to speak, that the benches have decidedly emptied out. It looks as though the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) is about to add further to that general exodus.

PARA.TAB: I do want to pick up a point that the member for Page made in his closing remarks when expressing some concern about the rush to privatisation, for want of a better word, that had followed both the IC report and the Hilmer report. He said that he thought it would be a responsible thing to bring that rush to privatisation back a little. My reassurance for the member for Page is that, frankly, what he has just said means that he ought to be supporting the opposition amendment, because that is just what the opposition amendment will do. It says, `Let's ensure that the community service obligations are enhanced and the community made even more aware of them.' All that the amendment foreshadowed by the member for Grey will seek to do is to ensure that Australia Post recognises the community service obligations it has, particularly to people in rural and remote communities.

I compliment the member for Page on a very constructive and considered speech about the legislation currently before the Main Committee. I have been following this debate and I have been a little distressed that some members of the government seemed to get very indignant at what was, in fact, nothing more than a constructive move by the opposition to reinforce the community service obligations. I followed with particular interest the speech by the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), who, in his usual way, attacked the opposition for what we were proposing to do by way of these amendments. The member for Watson was very proud, not only of Australia Post, but of the former PMG—with which I understand he had had an association during his working life.

Australia Post has a great deal to be proud of. The changes that have occurred in Australia Post are changes that Australians have generally refused to recognise. The Australia Post we have today is a very different organisation from the old PMG. The changes that have occurred to Australia Post are changes of which we should all be proud. What Australia Post has done has been to adopt the political philosophy of the opposition. It has simply said, `Let us become more capitalist and less socialist.' The change in Australia Post has been a move from a socialised PMG, which was a government department through and through, to an Australia Post with a real sense of competition and a real sense of desire to offer service to the Australian community because there are other people also offering a similar competitive service.

Australia Post ought to laud proudly the fact that it has picked up the philosophy I believe in—`Let us be exposed to competition and let us be prepared to work within the marketplace, hopefully profitably.' What has Australia Post done? As a result of getting a little more capitalist, it has turned a perpetual loss situation into a profit situation. Although this is not frequently recognised by the post office using community, Australia Post has not only turned a loss situation into a profit situation but it has also offered a return on the investment that the government has in Australia Post. The government is to be commended. Its decision to turn Australia Post into a GBE has resulted in a success story, because in developing Australia Post it has picked up the fundamental philosophy of the opposition and injected it into the old PMG.

What is the Australia Post story? It is a remarkable story, the story of an organisation that every year handles 4.2 billion articles of mail. Last year on its busiest day, 17 December 1993, it handled 44 million articles of mail. As the honourable member for Page has said, it delivered 42 per cent of those articles on time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ninety-two per cent.

—I thank the honourable member for Page for his interjection. This is an organisation that delivered 92 per cent of those articles on time. It has had a five per cent rise in productivity and it has maintained this service at a basic rate of 45c, which has not changed since 1992. In spite of that basic rate, Australia Post has continued to improve the profitability that it has offered in balance sheet terms and the return on investment that it has offered its principal shareholder, the government.

PARA.TAB: Had the postal rate that existed in 1975 been allowed to keep up with inflation, a basic postage stamp in Australia would now be valued at 69c, not 45c. The 45c stamp represents a real fall in terms of the revenue generated by Australia Post from what it would have been if pegged to the inflation rate of which the present government tells us it is so proud. Let us compare our 45c stamp rate with those across the globe. Expressed in Australian currency, the present rate in the UK is 54c; in Japan, 87c; and in Germany, 88c.

Australia Post has much of which to be proud, all of which has occurred since it was, for want of a better word, corporatised. It is fair to say that one could look around the globe and say, `Well, if Mr Andrew feels so proud of Australia Post, what about the New Zealand postal rate?' In Australian currency terms, I am told, the New Zealand rate is only 36c. I dare say that, if I said to Australia Post, `All you have to do is service Victoria and Tasmania', it too would be quite happy about pruning something off its 45c. The whole question of a comparison between serving Australia as if it were one place and serving New Zealand is the very point that the honourable member for Page raises with his community service obligations. I want to expand on that in just a moment.

Before turning to the CSOs, I will paint a picture of Australia Post as it is in its new, competitive environment, in its capitalist, rather than the former socialist, mode. Frankly, we have an Australia Post which has said, `Let's cease maintaining post offices, even in rural communities where it simply is not justifiable to have a postmaster standing there waiting for a Mr Woods or a Mr Andrew to appear at some time during the day.' Instead it has changed those offices, as all of us in rural seats—particularly the honourable member for Grey—are aware, into postal agencies. As a result, the postmaster has been doing a range of things apart from offering the postal service, and the postal service has been much more efficiently delivered. In fact, it was in the delivery of counter services that many of the losses of the original PMG were incurred.

I am one MP—in common with most federal MPs, I suspect—who has been invited by Australia Post to open the next stage of Australia Post's commercialisation. That is the retail post facility which is being offered at various post offices around rural electorates, allowing the post offices to engage not only in traditional post office business but also in the sale of all sorts of traditional stationery items such as cards, books and pencils. There has been some resistance to this, particularly from those who, for example, run the local newsagencies. It is felt that Australia Post enjoys an unfair advantage over the local newsagency.

I would not have been prepared to be involved in the opening of a retail post facility in my electorate—and I have been involved in the opening of one in Renmark and one in Waikerie over the last month, and there is one next month at Tanunda—unless I were first assured that Australia Post was obliged to conduct its business in precisely the same competitive environment as that of any other retailer. It is true to say that Australia Post still enjoys a monopoly on the sale of postage stamps and that, as a general rule—not as a perfect rule but as a general rule—in order for any other retailer to get access to the sale of postage stamps, he or she has to pay a licence fee. It is an area that ought to be, and I believe it will be, increasingly challenged by the government as it exposes Australia Post increasingly to the same retail pressure as everyone else.

That aside, my wife tells me that she is much more likely to go into the local newsagent to buy the daily newspaper or the things that she would normally acquire from the newsagent than she is to go, on a daily basis, into the local post office, particularly as our mail is delivered to our residential address.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that, it is fair to say that, with some of the monopoly that Australia Post enjoys, there is also a monopoly that is enjoyed by some retailers and, increasingly, as the parliamentary secretary has reassured me, this monopoly is going to be broken down under the capitalist instincts that have been picked up by the present socialist government.
—How will we pay for the CSOs?

—If the interjections do not distract me for too long, I hope to come to that item. I referred to it earlier in my speech. I welcome the changes that are occurring in Australia Post. I pick up much of what has been said by the member for Page in commending Australia Post on its level of efficiency and the profitability that has been shown.

PARA.TAB: I want now to turn to the whole question of CSOs, as I am invited to do by the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd). All that the opposition has done by its amendments is to reinforce the simple fact that there need to be CSOs, because a totally privatised Australia Post—as with a totally privatised any other government agency—would fail to deliver, under any party in power, the obligations that it has, either to the disadvantaged in the community if it were a normal government agency, or to rural communities, particularly in the case of Australia Post.

Frankly, I echo what the member for Page has said: we do need to balance this rush towards profitability against the community service obligations that we think essential services ought to deliver. It is for that reason that this amendment proposed by the opposition does nothing more than seek to ensure that people in rural communities get two mail service deliveries a week—not an unreasonable request. It is a reasonable request from the member for Grey which recognises that, particularly in his electorate, there are a large number of rural communities entitled to, not one, but two mail service deliveries a week.

The opposition has not sought to say that everyone should have mail delivered every day, or even that there ought to be more frequent letterbox deliveries, but has simply sought to ensure that those in rural communities are offered, not a remarkable, not an extravagant, but an acceptable service. That is all that this amendment currently does. The IC inquiry in 1991 actually asked that the commission clearly specify and make public the extent of the community service obligations that Australia Post has. We are simply following up that IC request by ensuring that the extent of those community service obligations is clearly understood.

The member for Leichhardt has asked who is going to pay. The member for Page, I would have thought, had largely answered that question when he indicated that the current estimation of community service obligations was calculated to be something like $46 million. Not unreasonably, he questioned the methodology used to arrive at that $46 million, but at no stage did he suggest that the community service obligations should in any way be further eroded. In fact, reflecting what is the rural nature of his electorate—and the nature of the member for Leichhardt's electorate is rural too, I hasten to add—he sought to ensure that those community service obligations would be maintained and that the rush to privatisation that we had seen under the IC and under Hilmer should not suddenly become the sole objective of Australia Post.

Frankly, I do not mind what the cost of the CSO is. I think it is not unreasonable to recognise that Australia Post is a government service, just like the Department of Social Security, which is offered to ensure that a particular facility is made available to all Australians. The purpose of the amendment pursued by the opposition is to ensure that the community service obligation is well understood and is not unreasonable. We believe that asking that mail be delivered as frequently as twice a week is not unreasonable in this day and age.

Australia Post has a proud history. The first post office was established in 1809 in Sydney and in 1901 the PMG, as we then knew it, came into being and existed in that form until 1975 when, as everyone knows, the communication facilities in Australia were split between Telecom and today's Australia Post. In 1989, to the government's credit, Australia Post became a government business enterprise. As I indicated in my opening remarks, its history since then, while chequered, has been largely successful.

What the government seeks to do is to ensure that Australia Post not only remains intact, not only remains efficient, not only picks up more capitalist and less socialist tendencies, but in addition to that recognises the community service obligations it has. We are not suggesting that Australia Post should be offering everybody a daily delivery but we make the point that in rural electorates a twice-weekly delivery is not unreasonable, is not an enormous burden to Australia Post and will distinguish Australia Post from other retail outlets. The cost of that is something that ought to be recognised and picked up by the taxpayers across Australia. I am proud to support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Postal Commission Amendment Bill 1994 implements the package of postal industry reform arrangements and further enterprise reforms for Australia Post. It was agreed by the government on 15 November 1993. The amendments are divided into two parts: postal industry arrangements, including Australia Post's obligations, reserve services, powers and obligations; and refinements to accountability and reporting arrangements, including tightening the circumstances where postal information may be disclosed for law enforcement and national security interests. Of course, there are other reforms which have been agreed by the government which have been implemented administratively.

PARA.TAB: The first point I want to make is one that the member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) made very well and that has been echoed by the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). I totally refute any suggestion that Australia Post and its workers are inefficient and have low productivity. Australia Post's productivity has improved at an average of 2.6 per cent a year since 1975. This is more than twice the average productivity growth of the whole of the Australian economy each year over those 15 years. This represents a steady increase in both revenue generated for each employee and the return on assets. The member for Page talked about the often quoted 5.1 per cent increase in the 1992-93 financial year.

Certainly there has been a great increase in productivity. An independent survey was taken of Australia Post letter delivery performance over the first three months of 1993 by KPMG Peat Marwick. It came up with the figures that 92.3 per cent of letters carried by Australia Post met or bettered its delivery timetable. Within one more day, the total of letters delivered to their destinations had risen to 98.3 per cent. Almost two-thirds of letters from the country to the capital city of the same state or territory arrived the day after posting. More than 72 per cent of letters from the country to the interstate capitals were a day early. More than 83 per cent of letters sent between country addresses were also a day early.

The parliament should pay tribute to the management of Australia Post and its workers for the efficient organisation that Australia Post is today. The parliament should—but I suspect the coalition will not—pay tribute to the Communication Workers Union and its predecessor, the Australian Postal Workers Union, for the part that they have played in achieving these great results by world standards. I notice that the honourable member for Wakefield talked about the efficiency of Australia Post but did not acknowledge, at any time, the input by Australia Post workers and their trade unions. That highlights the difference between this side of the House and the other side of the House.

Today, I want to concentrate on the delivery of postal services to rural and remote regions in Australia. Obviously, these reforms go together with the review of community service obligations in relation to rural and remote services which Australia Post is currently undertaking. There is also the very important reference to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure concerning Australia Post's community service obligations to rural and remote areas. This review, which must be completed in the life of the parliament, will enable not only members of this parliament, but also members of the public and organisations, to give evidence before that committee and to have an input into the community service obligations of Australia Post.

This is a very significant reform and I challenge those opposite to give an undertaking that, in the unlikely event of a coalition government, this opportunity for public and parliamentary scrutiny will continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't bet on it.
—I am not sure if that is an ambiguous statement. I am not so sure that I have got the faith that you have in the coalition—
—I will put my board up again.

—It is unlikely and I will not speculate any more in the realms of fantasy. But if a future government wishes to diminish the community service obligations of Australia Post, it would have to justify this to the parliamentary committee, to the House of Representatives and to the people of Australia. If the government rejected the recommendations of such a committee it would stand condemned.

PARA.TAB: The work of the rural task force, established by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), must be acknowledged, and I will also acknowledge the work of my colleague, the honourable member for Page. The Prime Minister's rural task force has already been looking at the RAAS—by that, I do not mean the rural adjustment scheme; I am referring to the rural air subsidy—and the task force has visited my electorate of Leichhardt and the electorate of the Northern Territory. The task force spoke to people in my electorate, including a meeting of the Cape York Peninsula Development Association. The National Party did not like it when we came to northern Australia. It has no real answers to the problem with the RAAS. At the time, the Nationals could only offer a scare campaign, saying that the government would abolish the RAAS. That is absolute nonsense. On the contrary, the government is committed to the betterment of Australia Post and Australia Post's community service obligations to rural and remote Australia.

The National Party does not like it when members of the Labor Party actually represent rural and remote regions. It does not like it at all. The Nationals think that it is their patch and that no-one else should come in, but I have got news for them—the people in rural and remote Australia recognise that the Labor Party is now the party of country people. The Labor Party is the party that looks after regional Australia and the amendments that are before this committee today illustrate just how out of touch the coalition is.

The task force found that the major use of RAAS was to deliver mail. I will choose my words very carefully here. RAAS charterers deliver not only letters but also educational matter from the School of Distance Education. They also provide pharmaceutical supplies as well as small parcels. That is all arranged through Australia Post. Australia Post is conducting its current review into its delivery network in remote Australia. It has given consideration to the special education and health needs of remote families, as well as consideration of particular climatic conditions. And, of course, that is very relevant to my electorate.

People in remote areas do not generally expect more than a weekly mail service. I am not suggesting that we change that. I am not going to give the coalition an opportunity to put around in my electorate some statement that the honourable member for Leichhardt does not support a twice-weekly mail service. That is not true. But if we talk about priorities and we talk to people in rural and remote regions in Australia, they do not jump up and down and say, `We want a twice-weekly mail service.' What they want is a regular, reliable, weekly mail service—and not just a letter service, I might add. I must emphasise that representatives of rural and remote communities will be invited to contribute to the review.

I want to make a separate point here. Remote Aboriginal and Islander communities in my electorate and in other parts of northern Australia are developing out-station movements which provide an alcohol-free environment on their traditional lands. This is a very important movement. It has been supported by the government and it has been supported by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs as well as by ATSIC and other Aboriginal organisations. Any rural CSO of Australia Post must include an obligation to provide a regular mail service to Aboriginal out-stations. This will be vital for their future, especially in terms of their educational and health needs.

I welcome also in the legislation and the complementary administrative arrangements the minister's request to Australia Post to establish audit mechanisms to report annually, and examine how it meets CSO delivery performance standards.

I am going to return to the coalition's proposals because in my view they should be rejected as not addressing the real problem. According to the Industry Commission, according to a 1992 survey, 156,677 households did not receive a mail delivery at all in Australia. That is 2.4 per cent of all households. That included 124,551 households in rural Australia, 27,236 of them in my state of Queensland. This should be the target of increased community service obligations in rural and remote areas.

Those who spoke to the Prime Minister's task force in my electorate and in the electorate of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) did not press hard for the extension of the services they already had. As I said earlier, they did not say they did not want an extension, that they would not want it. Of course, all Australians would want a daily mail service if they could have it, but that is not what people said to us. They said that they wanted those areas that did not have a mail service to have that mail service and they thought that a weekly mail service was adequate at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly for education and health.

—The honourable member for Page reminds me of the education and health requirements, and I will get back to that. I do not want to overestimate this but obviously in an area where Telecom has expanded, certainly in my electorate, to the most remote areas, letters are becoming a little bit out of date. People can use the telephone. It is not that important any more to get a letter from a friend but it is important, as the honourable member for Page emphasises, to get a parcel of educational material once a week. It is important that people get the pharmaceutical supplies that they need if they are in a rural or remote community and cut off in the wet season.

PARA.TAB: That is the important emphasis and that is why the coalition is out of touch. That is where we should be looking towards an increase in the CSO—not at a twice-weekly delivery service to areas that already have mail deliveries. Remember, 2.4 per cent of Australians do not get a mail service at all.

I do not deny that in the medium term our goal should be to increase the scope of CSOs. I invite the coalition to put its proposition to the proper parliamentary committee. That is the process that the government has set up. The coalition seems to have grabbed on to the Industry Commission report. It recommends that roadside delivery, which is now once a week, should be increased to at least twice a week. It was stated in that report that in 1992, according to Australia Post—and this is interesting—the cost of upgrading to two services a week for those now receiving only one service a week would be at least $3.7 million a year—or $1,162 a year for each of those 3,000 households. The report further states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the doubling of the service would result in a threefold increase in the present cost of providing mail services. This arises because the full cost of providing the extra run would be attributable to the mail since contractors are unlikely to receive any increase in earnings from the carriage of other goods.
I would say that that would also apply to delivery services under RAAS.

PARA.TAB: The Industry Commission seems to be really confused about the differences between the letter service and the mail service. It initially refers to the importance of the mail service to remote communities but then on page 110 it talks about education services being `distributed through the letter service to the outback'. However, the School of Distance Education in Queensland, for example, obviously delivers its materials in large parcels. The Prime Minister's task force saw the evidence in the form of those parcels.

I wonder what the cost of the Industry Commission's suggestion would be to Australia Post. A twice-weekly letter service would really mean nothing to people. If that were the CSO, it would be no help to people in rural and remote areas because they would be deprived of a parcel service. I am not sure whether the coalition members know what they are talking about in this matter, and I am afraid the Industry Commission is a little mixed up in that regard.

It is my view that a priority must be given to the mail service. The priority should be to provide a mail service to all Australian households as far as possible. Obviously, there are going to be some exceptions to that, but I think we can reduce that figure of 2.4 per cent of Australians who do not receive a mail service. However, if the guarantee is only a letter service, even if it is twice a week, how does that help people in rural and remote areas?

I understand that the coalition amendments go a little bit further by calling for changes to the definition of organisations and for extended services of document exchange, as I understand it. This would clearly undermine Australia Post. I interjected in the speech of the honourable member for Wakefield by asking how the extended CSOs the coalition is calling for would be paid for. The coalition proposal on document exchange certainly would not pay for them because that would undermine Australia Post by increasing further competition. It would obviously undermine the profitability of Australia Post and its capacity to deliver CSOs, especially to rural and remote areas. Honourable members should remember that the IC said that, even on the basis of a letter service, what the coalition is proposing would cost $3.7 million per year. That is the Industry Commission view.

What is the hidden agenda today? Does the coalition support the recommendation from the Industry Commission that Australia Post should be funded through the budget and not through the current method, which is, quite frankly, cross-subsidisation? I do not mind saying that and those honourable members on this side of the House do not mind talking about or supporting cross-subsidisation. The honourable member for Page talked about the balances that have to be taken into account in relation to that, and I agree with him. Does the coalition support that recommendation? What is its policy on this matter? On the one hand, the amendments that are being moved would diminish the profitability of Australia Post. On the other hand, $3.7 million—or probably more—would increase the cost of CSOs. If that is going to come off the budget, where are the deficit daleks now? Where are those who are calling for decreased public spending now?

TALK.START.PARA: —Deficit daleks?
—That is right, daleks. That is what you are.
—We'll call you Dr Who.

—I will ignore the interjections of the honourable member opposite. In conclusion, in relation to these reforms that have been introduced by the government, it is no secret that there was a lot of concern by trade unions, the labour movement in general and people in remote areas. There was a bit of a coalition warning against these reforms; it was said that they would undermine the profitability of Australia Post.

PARA.TAB: I agree with the honourable member for Page. I do not think these reforms will do that. I think it is fair to say that, on this side of the House, these reforms are seen as the bottom line. I do not welcome the comments of the coalition, evidenced in the amendments that are being moved today. They go down the deregulation path to introduce further competition to Australia Post. Let us make no mistake about this: if further competition is introduced, it will affect the capacity of Australia Post to deliver community service obligations, in particular, to rural remote areas. There is no doubt about that and that will be the net effect of the coalition's amendments. I suspect that the first part about a twice weekly mail service is a bit of a sweetener that the coalition has put in for its own constituency. The real ideological agenda is seen in the other amendments and the effect of those will be the ultimate destruction of Australia Post. If we ever do get a coalition government, I wonder whether the privatisation of Australia Post would come close to the top of the agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we get another Labor government in, it will be sold.
—Well, you say that. All right. Can you give a guarantee today that you will not sell it?
—No.
—We certainly won't.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Order! The honourable member's time has expired and the time for verbal jousting has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable members who have spoken in this debate. One gets the impression that it has been fairly wide ranging in terms of the approach that has been adopted on the issues. Naturally, honourable members have been concerned about a range of matters to do with postal services relating to all parts of Australia, and that is quite a legitimate and genuine perspective to have. I particularly thank the members of the government who have been part of the discussion process on what is a major step forward in the process relating to the Australian postal services.

PARA.TAB: The provisions before the House are designed to ensure that we carry through the government's response to the Industry Commission report which dealt with a range of issues relating to mail, courier services, parcel services, et cetera. In agreeing to increase competition in the postal sector, the government determined that a phased approach should be adopted. That was designed essentially to do three things. First of all, it was designed to safeguard the basic letter service so that it continues to cost the same to send a standard letter anywhere in Australia—that is currently 45c. It was also designed to ensure that the benefits of competition are phased in to consumers and business in the form of price restraint, with standard letter prices being subject to a price cap. At the same time, we are encouraging competition in value-added services such as bulk mail, document exchanges and express mail, and working towards the changes recommended in the Hilmer report on national competition policy.

Australia Post will remain in government ownership as a statutory corporation operating a national network, but it will face competition in new areas. I can give a commitment on behalf of the government that we are absolutely committed to maintaining Australia Post as a publicly owned government business enterprise. This competition is expected to provide the impetus for Australia Post to continue to improve its services but, at the same time, face competition in the new areas. As part of that process, we are ensuring that new competition comes in, offers the benefits that flow from that, but does not jeopardise services to rural areas or require closure of corporate post offices. There is no broad community support for ending Australia Post's reserved letter service. That is the first point to make in relation to the recommendations of Hilmer. The Industry Commission was unable to identify the costs or benefits from full deregulation of the postal industry.

It is clear that a phased approach has worked well in the telecommunication sector and we certainly believe that that is the appropriate methodology here. There have been significant decreases in prices across the board in the telecommunication area, and both business and residential customers are benefiting from that. New services are being introduced, service quality has improved and the telecommunications market has grown significantly as a result. Consistent with this approach, the government has determined a similar balanced strategy in relation to the postal sector, with the remaining limits on competition to be reviewed in 1996-97.

The opposition talks a lot about competition—although the debate shows that there is a fair amount of inconsistency in the approach that it adopts to these issues—so it is worth going through what the government's approach means in this area. We have ensured that there has been a significant restructure in the operations of Australia Post, and a number of government members have already referred to that. Australia Post has gone from a public service entity with a poor industrial record to a very efficient and profitable enterprise that operates at the forefront of world best practice and delivery service.

It is certainly time to build on that constructive base, while setting in place the changes in the regulatory framework to provide competitive disciplines to ensure that services are provided in the most efficient and economic way to Australian businesses and households. That phased approach that I referred to earlier encourages competition in value added services such as bulk mail, document exchange and express mail. At the same time, and importantly, it safeguards the basic letter service so that a standard letter to anywhere in Australia continues to be 45c.

We are also ensuring that the benefits of competition are passed on to consumers and businesses in the form of price restraints, with the standard letter price being subject to that price cap regime. We are working towards the recommendations outlined in the Hilmer report, but we are doing it in a way that matches what is a constructive and timely approach to these issues. For all the chest beating about competition policy, I think Australia Post is an example of how a constructive and deliberative approach to competition can produce efficiencies on the way through, but in a managed way. And I think that is the appropriate thing to do.

Australia Post will remain in government ownership as a statutory corporation operating a national network. It already has competition in 40 per cent of its revenue. As a result of these decisions, we expect that competition to spread to about 50 per cent of the corporation's revenue. This competition is expected to provide the impetus for continuing improvement in Australian Post services, such as we have witnessed in recent times.

The bill introduced by the government represents an important part of the reform of the sector. Nevertheless, individual aspects of it have come under scrutiny, and some pressure has been brought to bear in the form of amendments to address the particular concerns of some interests. It is for this reason that the government does not want to amend specific aspects of this package. It has already been the subject of major processes, certainly in terms of the discussions in the Senate.

The most significant area in which we have accepted an alternative approach is in relation to catalogues and leaflets. The government did not oppose the Democrat amendment to the bill in the Senate as it essentially maintains the status quo under the 1989 act and accords with current practice. It has never been the intention to deregulate advertising mail. The proposed amendments maintain that position, neither liberalising nor clawing back current legitimate activity.

Under the provisions of the bill, catalogues and leaflets—irrespective of whether or not they are directed to a particular person or address, or enclosed—continue to be exempt from Australia Post's exclusive right to carry letters, given under section 29 of the act. Australia Post will still have reserved to it deliveries of all letters, including generic or pro-forma letters of the kind tabled yesterday by my colleague the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Bevis). A leaflet or catalogue that is carried with a letter of a kind which is not exempt under any paragraph of section 30 will continue to be reserved to Australia Post, as is the case under current legislation. The amendment will not prevent the enclosure or attachment of a single sheet, fly sheet or an address slip with a catalogue or leaflet the sole purpose of which is to direct the item to a particular person or address.

The opposition amendment which was defeated in the Senate was unacceptable because it would have effectively deregulated this sector, which was never the government's intention. That is the sort of approach the opposition has taken to this proposal. With its amendments on document exchanges and its definition of an `organisation', it effectively wants to dismantle Australia Post's reserve services and to reduce the revenue stream with which Australia Post funds its community service obligations. That is quite the contrary of the sort of thing we heard earlier this morning.

Yesterday, opposition speakers used New Zealand as an example of effective competition in the postal industry. It is correct that New Zealand reduced price protection from 10 times to two times the standard letter rate in one step. What we did not hear from the opposition was that it resulted in the closure of 600 post offices and a reduction in New Zealand Post's net income from $31 million to 1988-89 to $5.4 million in 1991-92. This is exactly what the opposition's approach to these issues would mean in terms of Australia Post services. I understand that, in June 1993, the New Zealand government announced that the second stage of its postal reform process would not proceed, because there was no proven benefit to be gained from it.

It is quite ironic that, along with its amendments to deregulate the reserved service, the opposition wants to increase roadside deliveries to two a week. It claims to be doing this in the interest of rural dwellers, and a number of its speakers refer to that. But it is not in the interests of rural dwellers—far from it. It would have the effect of widening the gap between those receiving minimal services and those receiving none at all. It could even adversely affect the 3,000-odd dwellers currently getting by with one service per week.

What would be the approach of those opposite to these issues? Maybe they would adopt the sort of approach that was adopted in New Zealand, where an annual fee of $80 was imposed for rural deliveries. Of course, the problem would be magnified if that approach were adopted here. The amendment could result in the inequitable treatment of households currently receiving fewer than two deliveries per week, in that it proposes no increases for the 125 households which currently have no roadside delivery service available. The proposed amendment also runs the risk of preventing Australia Post from introducing one service per week in places where there are now no services and costs may preclude them from offering two.

The opposition members are proposing, through this approach, to substantially reduce the revenue streams which are available to Australia Post with which to provide the postal services which all Australians seek under its community service obligations. This policy, which I am surprised to see members from regional and rural areas support, would ensure that post offices would inevitably close, and postal services would be reduced in rural areas. Far from being a help, it would exactly follow the New Zealand model, and it would have the additional effect of threatening the 45c stamp price frozen by Australia Post until 1997.

The government has confirmed that the service standards to rural and remote areas will be maintained, and has agreed that a letter service will continue to be made available, at a uniform rate of postage, to all Australians, wherever they reside. The government's approach is to give rural and remote people a say in the postal services they expect. To safeguard rural and remote postal services, the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee), in conjunction with the member for Page (Mr Harry Woods), announced a further step in this regard, which was referred to earlier by a number of speakers. It is the review into Australia Post's community service obligations that is to be carried out.

The review is to be completed once in each parliamentary term. Representatives of rural and remote communities will be invited to contribute to the review. That will provide these communities with an opportunity to have a direct say in their postal services. Mr Deputy Speaker Fitzgibbon, as one who represents a regional area, I am sure you will be pleased that that review will be available and that you will be able to ensure that your constituents from the Hunter, as well as others, are able to actively participate in providing submissions to that review.

In addition, the bill allows for regulations to be made to prescribed performance standards for such things as mail deliveries. Appropriately, regulations will not be considered until after the completion of the parliamentary review of Australia Post's community service obligations. For the above reasons, I suggest to the House that this is an important reform. It is a balanced strategy which addresses the need for ongoing competition and the need for Australia Post to strive for best-practice standards. I am pleased to say that Australia Post has been achieving those standards in recent times. It has been meeting the challenge of competition.

These additional reform measures will add to the competition that Australia Post faces. At the same time, we are very conscious of wanting to ensure that the capacity exists for parliamentary reviews through the process that the minister has already announced. We also want to ensure that postal services are validly maintained across Australia, with the standard letter rate not being jeopardised by any action that might be taken because of the ill-conceived amendments that have been proposed in the course of this debate. I commend the bill to the House.
