TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to rise to support the government's initiatives in the superannuation area. The amendments to the superannuation legislation proposed by this bill, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, further add to this government's commitment to superannuation, particularly in the supervision of superannuation funds.

PARA.TAB: There has been quite a bit of discussion lately regarding superannuation and the safeguards that are in place. That is not unusual, of course. Whilst I accept completely the principle that matters for debate before the Main Committee are of a non-controversial nature, and I will certainly do my best to stick to that principle, I know that we do tend to take the opportunity in the debates here to discuss the issues and I think that it is important for us to be able to that. Before I comment, it would be remiss of me not to mention some of the comments from the opposition.

Those members who remained in the House of Representatives after question time on 11 October were treated to shameful scaremongering by the member for Ryan (Mr Moore) when initiating debate on his MPI on superannuation funds. According to him, the government wants to get its hands on the funds in order to pay for lunch. I am quite serious: that is actually what he said. I welcome the opportunity to contribute to the debate and provide a few facts to offset the rhetoric of certain members of the opposition, particularly in that MPI debate. There were some quite outrageous comments.

It was encouraging to see that the opposition supported this bill in the Senate. We have suggested that the opposition do the same here. I hope it will. It would be the best course to take and certainly in the best interests of the supervision of superannuation funds. I am sure there are many members of the opposition who are genuinely concerned about the savings of Australian workers and I commend them for that. They have the opportunity to do something about it today by giving their support to this bill and taking the opportunity to speak in support of it.

The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 makes a number of amendments to the Superannuation Industry Superannuation Act 1993 and the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993. As members would be aware, those acts form the centrepiece of a package of superannuation legislation which gave effect to the new prudential requirements arrangements for superannuation that the then Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, announced on 21 October 1992.

This bill seeks to amend these acts to further enhance and improve their operation. That is its major and only purpose—nothing else. There is nothing sinister in the form of compelling superannuation funds to invest in certain areas. I do not have a difficulty with that. I hope that members opposite will bear that in mind when speaking on this particular bill.

The bill will provide even stronger protection for the savings of Australian workers in superannuation. This is an issue I have been interested in for many years. Members would no doubt be aware of my previous comments on superannuation legislation. Whilst I do not claim to be an expert in superannuation, my background in the banking industry, particularly in trade union superannuation funds and also as an investment adviser in the banking industry where I had a lot to do with superannuation funds, has given me broad industry experience on how important superannuation funds are for Australian workers. That experience puts me in a more informed position than some of the members opposite who made scaremongering attacks recently, and makes me more informed than the member for Ryan, who made comments in the debate on the matter of public importance that I referred to earlier.

It is not surprising that the member for Ryan was concerned about free lunches. It took a Labor government to put a stop to those, much to the continuing chagrin of the BMW set. Perhaps the member for Ryan was thinking back to the `good old days' where free lunches were the order of the day.

There have been a lot of changes made to superannuation legislation over the past few years. On this side of the House we are aware that these constant changes cause some concern in the community and the business sector. They are essential to ensuring the safety of superannuation funds and the promotion of superannuation for people's retirement. However, the government will not just sit still and do nothing when it sees where improvements must be made. We have to respond to the needs of an ever changing society. These changes apply to a range of issues, and certainly to superannuation. We can be proud of the record that this Labor government has in the superannuation area. General retirement incomes policy has been a real focus of this government.

Whilst these changes may create uncertainties, they are implemented to protect the savings of Australian workers and are essential to the safety of superannuation funds. That will always be the primary concern for the government in this area.

A range of amendments in this bill seek to improve the legislation. Making provision to allow certain non-bank financial institutions to offer approved guarantees required under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act is one of those amendments. Currently only approved banks and the Commonwealth, states or territories can offer the guarantee required under the act. Building societies, credit unions and other financial institutions are subject to the various state financial institutions codes.

The government considers that these should also be able to offer the guarantees required under the act. If the opposition required proof of the government's commitments to protecting superannuation savings, it need look no further than this amendment. We are placing additional superannuation funds held in these institutions under the strictest superannuation safeguards in the country. When one considers the growing popularity of credit unions and building societies, this amendment should be welcomed. It will give greater protection to significant amounts of money.

Allowing in-house investments in certain non-bank financial institutions is another example of how the government is giving greater protection to workers' superannuation savings. For the benefit of members unfamiliar with the concept, an in-house investment is simply a loan to an employer sponsor of a superannuation fund. This bill amends the SI(S) Act to place restrictions on the level of these investments.

Another amendment concerns application for the issue of superannuation interest and application to become a standard employee sponsor. As the explanatory memorandum outlines, the bill amends the SI(S) Act to ensure that the trustee cannot accept a person as a member of a public offer entity unless that person has applied in the appropriate manner and has received relevant information determined by the commissioner regarding the entity before doing so.

Perhaps the most important aspect of the legislation concerns public offer superannuation funds and equal representation. At the moment, the SI(S) Act requires an employer sponsored fund which is a public offer fund to have an independent trustee. This bill will amend the act to allow such funds to have a greater flexibility in choosing the trustee. It will give them the option of having an independent trustee or having equal numbers of employer and member representatives involved in the trusteeship of the fund. Think about that: actually encouraging members of a superannuation fund, workers themselves for the most part, to play a role in supervising their own money. This provides for funds with greater flexibility in organising their trusteeship while at the same time ensuring that members are protected by having a trustee who is independent, or by having direct involvement in the fund through having equal representation.

Allowing the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to provide protected information to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal is another important area. The bill amends the SI(S) Act to allow the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to provide protected information relating to the affairs of the fund to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. Anyone who has had dealings with constituents over their problems with a superannuation fund would know the benefits this amendment will bring.

The tribunal began operations on 1 July this year, and has been largely hailed as a quick and relatively easy forum for dealing with complaints from members of superannuation funds. However, one of the major failings has been caused by the restriction of protected information, particularly where that very information relates to a specific case. This has caused delays and frustration for those people who have been trying to find out information about their fund through the complaints tribunal, so this can only be viewed as a very positive development.

Another amendment will ensure that disqualified persons are not to be custodians of superannuation funds—a logical provision which probably should always have been there. The act currently restricts disqualified people from becoming trustees or investment managers of superannuation funds. There is, however, no similar requirement on custodians of the funds. Once again, the government has recognised the possible danger to workers' savings that this shortcoming in the act represents, and this bill will address the problem. The act will be amended to ensure that the custodians are subject to eligibility requirements similar to those that already apply to trustees and investment managers.

This amendment will also create an offence of intentionally acting as a custodian where the person in question is, and knows they are, a disqualified person. The penalty for this is two years imprisonment. I am sure we will all agree that that will serve as a deterrent to some of the less savoury types in the finance field. I am sure we have all heard the stories of con men wrecking people's lives.

The bill also provides for the removal of trustees of public offer entities. The bill will amend the act by inserting a new requirement that prevents another party from trying to exert influence on a trustee by threatening to remove the trustee unless he or she agrees to comply with that party's request. This will be done by ensuring that unless the regulations provide otherwise, no person other than the commissioner can remove a trustee of a public offer fund.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this aspect of the bill is an extremely important and praiseworthy one, particularly when you realise the sorts of figures we are talking about in relation to superannuation. In March this year, the total value of assets in superannuation funds across Australia topped $186 billion. This represents an astonishing 14.5 per cent increase on the total value of assets held in these accounts in the last 12 months. Some 6.1 million Australians aged between 15 and 74 are covered by a superannuation scheme. Superannuation premiums increased by an incredible 38 per cent in the year ending December 1993, to total more than $6.3 billion, so we are talking about vast sums of money here. That money belongs to Australian workers, and it is vital that we provide adequate protection for approved trustees and custodians of superannuation funds to ensure that they do not feel compelled to offer an investment strategy, for example, that would benefit anyone unduly.

This is not as far-fetched as it may at first sound, because 29.7 per cent of the superannuation assets are invested in shares, 7.7 per cent in short term securities and 6.8 per cent in property. We have 44.2 per cent of funds invested in what have proven to be quite lucrative areas, and the temptation would be there for any unscrupulous operators to attempt to increase a fund's exposure to the share market and property particularly. Investment strategy is a topic that tends to involve average fund members only at the annual shareholders meetings, by which time it can be too late to ask questions of the fund managers. Keep in mind also that it is other people's money they are investing.

The great majority of fund investment managers are professional and highly responsible people. I acknowledge that. But when such vast sums of money are at stake, it is quite right that we acknowledge that the temptation will always be there to manipulate responsible investment strategies, overexposing a portfolio to the shares or derivatives market, for example, for personal gain. It is an important area that we really have to home in on. This temptation not only endangers the savings of workers and average Australians, but it also places in jeopardy the large sums of money that have already been invested by Australian industry.

As at November 1993, employers paid all contributions for 75 per cent of part-time employees and 45 per cent of full-time employees. Employers would regard this as an investment in the future of their work force—and so they should—and, therefore, in the long-term future of their business. It is essential for them to have a good solid work force to assist them in the success of their business and hence, of course, to continue to promote job opportunities for all Australians.

Honourable members would be aware that I, along with other members, the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) included, have been calling for superannuation funds to invest more in Australia and in Australian industry, particularly in infrastructure development and other projects that would have long-term benefits to the economy, creating jobs for future Australians and, of course, current Australians as well. It is an issue that I have concerned myself with for many years. Currently, 82 per cent of total assets in superannuation funds are invested in Australia—which, of course, is pleasing. Some might see this as a good figure and, indeed, 82 per cent of $186 billion is not to be sneezed at. But the breakdown of areas where these assets are invested is more instructive than just percentage figures.

As I said before, nearly 30 per cent is in shares—which is fine, if you happen to be a member of a fund that picks a winner on the share market. Another 22.1 per cent is invested in long-term securities—which, once again, is fine; but government securities are not always used to pay for large scale, long-term infrastructure projects that will not only create jobs but actually encourage the start of completely new industries. A further 18 per cent of that total investment of $186 million is actually invested off-shore in overseas assets. The less than 30 per cent remaining is at present split up between short-term securities, which account for 7.7 per cent, and land and buildings, which account for 6.8 per cent, the remaining 16.7 per cent being spread across various other investment vehicles.

I happen to agree with the concept of a national pool of savings, which, of course, would ideally include a contribution from superannuation funds. But my idea would be something along the lines of only one per cent of the fund's assets being put into this national investment pool. That one per cent represents about $l.86 billion, which could be used to fund infrastructure projects that would not only be beneficial to future Australian workers, but would also—believe it or not—actually end up returning a profit to the investors themselves—who, of course, are the members of the superannuation funds. Such a small percentage as one per cent would not put any extra strain on the superannuation funds, and it would be a tremendous investment strategy to assist the growth of industry in Australia.

Contrary to what my colleague the honourable member for Ryan said in his MPI referred to earlier, this Labor government has never been interested in free lunches. We have only ever been interested in providing the best outcomes for all Australians: workers, industry, unions, communities, families—the list goes on. That is our commitment to this nation.

I suggest that encouraging the development of a national infrastructure fund—I will call it that, but it does not matter what it is called, as long as it is a fund that can invest in the infrastructure that the Minister for Transport and I agreed on—is another step in the process of real reform that this government has initiated over the years in the economy generally, and in the superannuation and investment markets in particular. Let me make it quite clear that such a scheme would be handled under the strictest possible supervision. That is the important part and that is what this bill is all about: supervision of superannuation funds.

This strict supervision would allow for the creation of investment consortia consisting of representatives from industry, unions, and the investment and finance sector—people who are on the ball and who know what they are doing on the industry and investment side. I do not have a difficulty with this, but it is important that the members of the fund also participate in it, whether it be through trade unions or trustees of the fund. Even superannuation funds themselves and any relevant statutory bodies that could approach the issue of long-term infrastructure needs from a new angle and with innovative investment plans could assist in a lot of the development of our industry.

The percentage of the contribution from the funds is a matter far too complicated to speculate on, but the figure of one per cent of total fund assets has been mentioned. Given the amounts I have mentioned, this is probably a reasonable starting point for debate on the issue. It could always be expanded: one per cent represents $1.86 billion, but two per cent would double that to about $3.7 billion very quickly.

The bill seeks to amend the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993, which is another important aspect of this bill and the amendments provided. I have gone through a number of the amendments, and I have expressed some views on superannuation funds because I think it is a very important area, and I think that we can never address it as much as we need to in this place. I believe that the government and the opposition should come together on these issues. When we are thinking about long-term strategies and long-term planning for people's retirement, it is important that our superannuation funds are well-managed and well-supervised.

This legislation is a further example of this government's commitment to retirement incomes and that is very important. Through superannuation funds, we can provide a better income than any government can provide under any social security system. I am very committed to the enhancement and promotion of superannuation funds, but it is important that all superannuation funds are well-managed and well-supervised. I am pleased that the government has brought forward amendments which will further enhance the strength and confidence of our superannuation funds. I thank members of the Main Committee for their time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, as has been pointed out by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), is essentially designed to ensure accountability and effective supervision of superannuation funds. It is to provide a fair and formal and economic mechanism to resolve disputes arising from superannuation. I was going to compliment my colleague on the substance of his speech and his obvious grasp of the importance of superannuation, until he made his latter comments, which horrified me, about the establishment of a national investment fund.

PARA.TAB: He has gone straight back to 1987 and reminded me of the ACTU report Australia Reconstructed. Ever since then, we have had more than a few members of the government continually playing with the concept of how nice it would be if only we could take one per cent of contributors' investment funds and put them into national infrastructure projects. This dream keeps appearing time and time again. It is interesting that only yesterday at the ASFA conference in Perth, the Treasurer (Mr Willis)—well aware of the very real concern that this attitude is having on the stability of investors within the industry and, above all, on contributors within the industry—went to considerable lengths to assure those present that the government does not intend to interfere in the decision making process of investors in relation to superannuation.

Therefore, I find it extraordinary, in the context of what the Treasurer said yesterday, that we should once again hear today this ageing theme of how nice it would be, if only we could use somebody else's money. If only we could get hold of one per cent—a mere $1.86 billion, we were told, of contributors' funds—they say, and put that to work for Australia's infrastructure. If only!

Of course, the truth of the matter is that any analysis of the law, any consideration of either this legislation or the earlier legislation in relation to the establishment of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act of 1983—known in shorthand as the SI(S) Act—lays down quite conclusively and with complete clarity the fact that trustees of superannuation funds have one fundamental responsibility and that is to ensure that, at all times, the investments made on behalf of their contributors are guaranteed in so far as it is possible to do so on the basis of the right decisions being made, in the interests of the contributors.

I reiterate that they must be made in the interests of the contributors—not in the interests of the Australian people, not in the interests of whatever Australian government may be there at the time, not to achieve the policy objects of whatever government may be in power at the time, but in the interests of the individual contributors. I find it extraordinary that members of the government, in the face of that unassailable legal requirement placed on trustees, and by extension placed on fund managers, can seriously put forward the proposition of how nice it would be if only they could get their sticky little fingers onto those billions and billions of dollars.

If what the honourable member said was an isolated case, one would be prepared to forgive it for what it was: the passionate dreams of a backbencher in the Labor government. Unfortunately that is not so. In 1987 the ACTU mission to Europe released its report Australia Reconstructed, in which one of its objectives was the establishment of a national investment fund. Is it not amazing that the figures we have just heard from the honourable member appeared in the written text of Australia Reconstructed back in 1987? Yes, it wanted one per cent too. Yes, it wanted to utilise superannuation funds to invest in national projects. Ever since that report, we have had many examples of ministers—and senior ministers at that, not just backbenchers—who have been only too willing to raise these issues.In a foreword to that report, Bill Kelty stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We care about nothing less than the reconstruction of Australia.

We all care for the reconstruction of Australia—it is not just Mr Kelty, not just the ACTU, not just the Labor Party. We all care for it because it is the basis of the creation of job opportunities for our own generation and for those of our children.

PARA.TAB: That does not, in any sense, deny the fact that we cannot have a policy at a national level which interferes in the rights of the individual to make contributions to a superannuation plan, the ostensible objectives of which, according to government policy, no less, are that those people should have greater financial independence in their retirement. But ever since 1987 this ghost, if I may use that term, has come to reappear in various guises on the most extraordinary occasions. Time and time again it reappears. Hooper, Gilchrist and Way in the Business Review Weekly on 12 April 1991 referred to the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), then a Labor backbencher. The article said:

SPEECH.PARA: O'Keefe argued that super funds provide a long-term capital base that should be tapped—provided the terms are attractive. Perhaps more importantly, it is consistent with Labor philosophy: a similar line of argument was advanced in the ACTU's 1987 Australia reconstructed . . .

In recent days, we have seen none other than the Minister for Transport apply the `provided the terms are attractive' principle. He came up with a wonderful scheme to get rid of the Australian National Line. His further extension of that philosophy was to try to get rid of a few airports. The concept was `Australian social investment'. The proposal he put forward was quite straightforward. He would offer the trade unions a shareholding in ANL, for example, and, in return for that, nobody would have to pay any tax, except, of course, the Australian taxpayers. They would pay more; but the workers in the industry would not pay tax.

PARA.TAB: In other words, he was finding a mechanism to ensure that, ultimately, one would have to say, `Who could possibly say no to such an outstanding deal?'. I remind honourable members that the minister himself had said, only weeks before, that the ANL `could not be given away'. But he is quite happy to massage the figures in such a way that the funds of employees of those unions contributing to superannuation schemes can be given away. Apparently, their money can be given away with total cynicism, because there is a view in the ALP that what they think does not count.

It does count for the opposition. It is a fundamental principle of our approach to social security and superannuation issues that, where people make investments expecting that those funds will be managed wisely for their long-term superannuation and retirement income purposes, they can be protected by the system. We will never lie down and see a government, by one stratagem or another, change the rules of the game in such a way as to take from those individual investors—little people though they might be—the right to have security in

SPEECH.PARA: retirement, and the right to depend upon the integrity of the system to which they have been required by law, whether they like it or not, to make contributions.

PARA.TAB: The record goes right back to 1991, when the then Treasurer, now the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), teamed up with his old mates, the then Senators Richardson and Button—who have both now left us—to wage what proved to be an unsuccessful campaign aimed at getting superannuation funds to invest more high-risk venture capital in their projects.

The line they took was that the funds were getting rich only because of the government's superannuation strategy, and that, in return, the funds should be prepared to put money back into areas which would stimulate the economy. At one point, the then Senator Richardson made some not-so-veiled threats that, if the super funds did not comply, the government might have to take stronger measures to point them in the right direction. `Don't do what I do; do what I say' was quite clearly the principle that they were prepared to apply.

In the same year, the then Senator Button—who was the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce—advocated a $1 billion fund for developmental capital. Six big financial institutions were asked to provide $100 million each, to form the basis of Development Capital Ltd, an investment vehicle aimed at medium-sized companies with export prospects in the traded goods area. Trustees of super funds would invest in a company which would have its own board and management team. A series of other projects were put forward by various people in the same year.

In 1993, the then Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), admitted that the government's industry policies had failed to create a climate in which adequate supplies of capital were available to small and medium-sized enterprises. He pointed out, rightly, that a solution was needed.

But he did not remove some of the barriers to business investment, which is clearly one of the answers to the problem. He did not even follow the suggestion of another former senator, Susan Ryan, who is now the executive director of ASFA. As was noted in the Financial Review of 7 December 1993, she suggested:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . encouraging the small business sector to better promote itself would resolve the government's predicament.

The member for Maribyrnong went on to suggest that the government was looking for means `by which superannuation fund managers, or for that matter, capital providers more generally, can be encouraged to invest more of their funds in small and medium-sized enterprises'. Again, it is the fist in the velvet glove that we have seen operating, to one degree or another, for the best part of this decade. Anyway, the honourable member's proposal did not get off the ground either.

PARA.TAB: In the face of all of this, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott)—I am glad to see he is in the chamber now—assured the industry that `the government considers that it is generally more appropriate for superannuation funds to be managed and invested along commercial lines in the private sector'. Well may he say that! I sincerely hope that the industry will believe him. Unfortunately, it does not, because it can read; it can also hear. Its members are sensible men and women who can make judgments. They realise that the weight of those judgments will affect hundreds of thousands of Australians and, as we are told, enormous investments made by Australians in superannuation for which they, by law, are accountable and responsible—not the government of the day.
I mentioned the efforts of the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith. He made an observation on this which I think is worth quoting. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will take all steps necessary, including an indication of preference in tender documents, to maximise the participation in bidding consortia by Australian superannuation funds, especially industry funds.

Guess what? Who has at least 50 per cent of the influence in the determination of funding decisions through industry funds? It is the trade union movement. With whom are they associated? The ACTU. So whatever road is taken, one comes back to good old Australia Reconstructed—that report released by the ACTU back in 1987.

PARA.TAB: That is the blueprint for the utilisation of superannuation investments in Australia. One does not have to go beyond that document to see precisely what is this Labor government's hidden agenda. Yes, of course, it is wonderful to be able to turn on the tap of finance and be able to inject it where you will. Look what Labor has achieved in recent years in looking for this fabled good result from investment. In Western Australia, there was WA Inc. and the catastrophe that brought upon the state, as well as on the Labor movement. There was the fiasco and the failure of the South Australian bank; there were the fiascos in Victoria.

So the riddle wrapped in the mystery of incompetence goes on and on—all because Labor worked on the principle, the flawed principle, that other people's money is easier to control and direct than actually encouraging people to earn money legitimately by changes to micro- and macro-economic policy which effect the overall outcome and make it more effective for people to get a maximum return for their investment.

Out of the taxes that could then be gained, the government could make whatever decisions a government is prepared to put before this parliament. But, no, it had to take the back road. It had to take the smart road—a road which left hundreds of thousands of retired Australians in a situation where their long-term financial viability was put at enormous risk. In many cases they lost their shirts. I have never heard from any responsible state minister or, in a vicarious sort of way, from members of this government, who have now been in office for 11 years, any serious suggestion that mistakes were made which should not have been made. The courts alone have been the authority which has put these people where they belong, behind bars. So many Australians believe that ultimately was the test which they had to sit for, and which they certainly failed.

May I make the coalition's position abundantly clear. The coalition does not believe that governments should in any way meddle or tamper with investments or savings of Australians in this country or elsewhere. Nor does the coalition believe that governments can force investment to happen. In government, consequently, the coalition will not mandate that superannuation funds must invest some proportion of funds in any particular type or class of Australian industry. We will not legislate to hinder or to penalise overseas investment by Australians. We will not use special tax deals to persuade institutions to invest in sectors or industries that would not otherwise be considered as worthwhile investments.

As I said, the government should keep its sticky fingers out of the Australian cookie jar. The cookies were put there by hundreds and thousands of individual contributors. It is their money, not the government's. It is their decisions which have to be taken seriously, not the decisions of government. The government's decision must be about providing the climate, the environment, in which fund managers can make the right decisions which will ultimately result in a more viable situation for everybody involved.

The legislation before us today covers a series of important subjects. They are essentially of an administrative nature; nevertheless they are a series of changes which will have a major impact on the quality of the SI(S) legislation over time. The amendments include: allowing approved guarantees to be given by certain approved non-bank financial institutions; permitting non-arms-length investment transactions, provided conditions are no more favourable than if the transaction were conducted at arms length; allowing for the use of independent trustees or bodies that contain equal representation of employers and members in the supervision of employer sponsored superannuation funds; and providing for the minister to approve public disclosure of information where this is in the public interest and does not unreasonably disclose the personal affairs of an individual.

The opposition supports all these amendments. They are sensible changes to what is one of the most significant pieces of social legislation to be introduced in recent years. However, there is no way that we are going to support the approach taken by the government by which it wants to interfere in the decision making processes of fund management. Ultimately, that approach is not in the interests of the individual contributor, and it is certainly not in the interests of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my contribution to this discussion on the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, I start with the observation made by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who preceded me, in the last two minutes and 25 seconds of his contribution, that this legislation contains a large number of very important provisions for the effective operation of superannuation in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I also acknowledge the advice that he gave—as did the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who I think led the discussion for the opposition on this legislation—that the opposition would not be opposing the legislation. We are delighted to hear that. We are also delighted to have the member for Bradfield confirm that the opposition is not opposing the bill because it recognises that it is good legislation.

I genuinely appreciate that comment from the member for Bradfield. He is a member of the opposition who has a particularly deep understanding of superannuation. He has been interested in this area for a long period of time. He has pursued it very effectively. For that reason, I know that he is aware of the government's formal position in relation to superannuation, superannuation funds and the way in which those funds are the property of the contributors and must be managed in an appropriate way for the benefit of those contributors.

The honourable member used expressions like `The public sector must keep its sticky fingers out of the people's assets.' The general thrust of that sort of thing, as the member for Bradfield knows, has been more than adequately endorsed by the government. There are occasions, quite understandably and quite legitimately, where members of the broader labour movement will give consideration to matters of concern to them. That necessarily will include, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know, the question of effectiveness of investment policy and ensuring that the flow of investment funds into areas of the kind about which they are concerned is encouraged to grow.

I wish to make reference to some of the observations that were made by the honourable member for Curtin when he led for the opposition in connection with this legislation. After he had completed dealing with the general form, arrangements, purposes and content of the bill, he then said superannuation policy under Labor had been a litany of wasted opportunities. Of course, members of the opposition coalition did support superannuation, but they supported it for the rich, for people with high incomes.
