TALK.START.PARA: —In November 1988, 51.3 per cent of the total number of employees in Australia were covered by superannuation. Back in 1983, it was about 30 per cent or perhaps even lower. As I have already indicated, and as everyone knows, that group consisted essentially of male high income earners. By November of last year, the percentage covered by superannuation increased to 80.5 per cent of the total number of employees in Australia. The numbers of full-time employed in November 1988 were 3,491,000, which increased by November 1993 to 5,119,000 and continue to grow. There has been a series of initiatives of enormous significance, a fact that was recognised by the honourable member for Bradfield in the concluding moments of his contribution.

PARA.TAB: These amendments are essentially concerned with questions of prudential and consumer protection and the arrangements that are and should be built into superannuation to ensure that that protection is accorded. That is essentially what this legislation is all about. The details were more than adequately indicated by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott), when he delivered the second reading speech. I do not want to go through all of those details again, but I think it is worth recording the essential elements of this legislation.

It will allow for certain non-bank financial institutions, for example, to offer approved guarantees within the provisions of the superannuation arrangements. It will allow in-house investments in certain non-bank financial institutions as well. Application for the issue of a superannuation interest and application to become a standard employer-sponsor are provided for within the legislation. It also deals with the acquisition of certain assets from members of regulated superannuation funds, the issue of public offer superannuation funds and equal representation, and the existing trustees and the provisions under which they may give notice of retirement.

The disclosure of information by the minister is an extension of the legislation. There are certain disclosures which are already provided for; this is a sensible and logical extension in connection with superannuation for the purposes which are indicated in the legislation. Likewise, allowing the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to provide protected information to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal is a perfectly appropriate provision. It gives consideration to the approved purposes of an approved deposit fund and payments to beneficiaries in such a fund; it deals with the question of disqualified persons, who are not to be custodians within the management arrangements of the funds; it deals with the question of the removal of trustees of public offer entities; and it deals with allowing exempted public sector superannuation schemes to become subject to the Superannuation Act 1993. In addition, there are a number of minor revisions. They are all of particular importance to the whole question of the effectiveness and the security with which superannuation funds operate.

In addition, there is the question of whether or not any government will be providing, in a prudential, secure and competent way, arrangements to more effectively deal with retirement incomes and, within the context of this government's approach, to ensure that retirement incomes are supplemented to provide more fully for the retirement comfort of Australians. Further to those considerations, there is also the general question of the important contribution which superannuation makes to the development and flow of savings in Australia, in order to make it possible for Australia, during this period of growth, to have access to sufficient investment resources to undertake the sort of investment that we need. That is important as well.

If those objectives are going to be achieved, it is absolutely essential that the superannuation funds and the arrangements under which they operate are placed on a sufficiently secure and prudentially proper foundation to have credibility. People need to feel confident that the contributions which are being made by them, and for them, are being made into arrangements which are credible and which will achieve the objectives that have been set.
I would like to mention a comment from Professor David Knox of Melbourne University. Professor Knox is an acknowledged authority on superannuation. He has commented:

SPEECH.PARA: The desire for a high level of confidence in the system has led the government to strengthen the prudential arrangements for superannuation with the SIS legislation and the general thrust of this legislation is to be applauded.

Professor Knox is a person whose competence in this area is well recognised; he does a lot of commissioned work on behalf of the superannuation industry. As an academic who is involved full-time in this area, he has put his imprimatur on what the government is seeking to do.

PARA.TAB: In a large and growing superannuation industry of the kind that we have in Australia, there is obviously a need for the prudential security that has been provided by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer. There is an enormous diversity of funds in Australia. I have some reservations about that diversity and the type of problems that it creates for the successful surveillance and supervision of the industry. There are 73,000 funds and some of those funds have less than five members. That is a matter to which consideration needs to be given. As of October 1993, over six million workers were covered by those funds.

I take special pride in saying that almost two million low income workers are included in that figure. When they retire, they may well depend primarily, as most Australians do, upon the age pension. However, the government is telling those people that it will make it possible for them, during their working lives, to accumulate an entitlement to superannuation benefits which will supplement the age pension, and which will make their retirement that much better. I believe that is something to be applauded. I applaud it and I applaud the general approach that this government has made.

I accept that some of the criticisms and concerns that have been raised about the number of changes made since 1983 are legitimate. But I emphasise that those changes have been made since 1983—since a Labor government was in the national parliament introducing changes to ensure that the whole of the superannuation structure was appropriate and that people were covered: they were safeguarded and their retirement would be complemented in such a way as to improve the quality of their lives in their retirement. The additional funds being generated would be directed in prudential and proper ways into investment arrangements in Australia. None of these things were undertaken prior to 1983. Why would there not have been changes since 1983?

We have the litany of wasted opportunities which the honourable member for Curtin referred to. The people on the opposition benches shout, rant, rave and interject in order to cover their own confusion, their inadequacy and their feeling of guilt because of that litany of wasted opportunities that in a sense they can, I suppose, claim credit for prior to 1983.

Australian superannuation funds at the present time hold assets in excess of $160 billion—closer to $180 billion. I have seen a number of figures for this and I am not sure which I can depend upon except the one provided to me by my good friend and colleague the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer. It is an enormous reserve of investment funds available to help develop this country as well as to provide for people in their retirement.

With regard to the initial three per cent productivity superannuation trade-off, the claim has been made that all the contribution towards industry superannuation at the present time is being made by employers. That is simply not correct. People say that the employers cannot afford it, yet they do not have to afford it. It came out of the pockets of workers. It was a trade-off against a productivity gain that would have put money into the pockets of workers and into their family budgets if it had been paid to them as a productivity wage increase. It was a remarkable response on the part of the trade union movement and the ACTU when they said that they were prepared to forgo that money in the pocket to help provide for retirement income. That was the first three per cent.

I know that later on there will be contributions which will be identified as contributions from employers, some of which have already started. But there is also a suggestion at this stage that towards the end of this period, during which the superannuation contribution as a proportion of wages will grow to about 12 per cent, the last three per cent will be considered as well to be a direct contribution from employees themselves. Let us not hear all of this nonsense about whether or not it can be afforded. Of course it can be afforded. It represents an effective national saving which needs to be afforded if we are going to have the capacity to fund the sort of investment that Australia needs in the future.

That minimum support, at the present time, is five per cent. If there were 100 per cent cover of all employees in Australia at the present time, in connection with that five per cent, that would be channelling into our investment and savings capacity $12,000 million every year. By the year 2002, when it will be up to nine per cent, again if that covers 100 per cent of employees, in today's dollar terms it will be ploughing in $22,000 million every year for investment purposes. That is a matter of enormous public sector importance and of enormous national importance, and is the sort of thing to which any responsible, planning, deliberate national government would give consideration.

Dr Vince FitzGerald in his national savings report estimated that the superannuation guarantee arrangements would eventually increase total private savings by about 1.25 per cent of GDP each year. In today's dollar terms, that amounts to 1.25 per cent of $425,000 million—$425 billion—or $5.3 billion each year. That is an enormous increase in the volume of funds which are going to be made available.

The government has been concerned to put in place a comprehensive superannuation system under which all Australians will be contributing to their own retirement incomes and helping to enhance their own retirement security and comfort. This will also be done by forgoing current consumption, which, of course, all savings represent.

The ACTU, the trade union movement and Australian employees have cooperated in this approach. Not only does it benefit them but also it benefits national purposes. The system has been designed to embrace everyone for the first time ever in the history of this Commonwealth and let the record show it clearly and proudly. For the first time ever, a national Labor government put in place a superannuation arrangement which will cover every Australian. It covers the question of portability for casual employees and part-time employees: they can build up a retirement benefit and they can carry it with them. The benefit will be maintained. The provisions have been put in place to ensure that the commission and other types of arrangements do not destroy that accumulated benefit. All these things have been put in place through the Taxation Office to ensure that these people receive protection and to ensure that they will benefit. This will grow progressively to ensure that the two fundamental elements are achieved: firstly, security in retirement; and, secondly, an appropriate flow of savings to guarantee the investment capacity of Australia now and increasingly into the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot imagine how a man who I believe is an intelligent person can proclaim as a virtue the predictable mess created by the government in the superannuation field. The incredible shambles of superannuation is driving people to other forms of investment. The unpredictable nature of what the government has created has meant that people are looking for alternatives for investment because superannuation is completely unsatisfactory.

PARA.TAB: For weeks, months and years, the government procrastinated on any decisions in regard to casual and part-time employees. The government knew the mess that it was creating. It knew how much it would cost part-time or casual employees; the cost of administration would take away the savings the government proclaimed it was making. It was put into the tax office and it turned the tax office into something that it should not be. I cannot understand why the honourable member has not been able to advance some further ideas for improvement instead of proclaiming that the situation is acknowledged nationwide amongst employees as completely unsatisfactory.

The changes have been applauded by the honourable member. Some of these changes seek to rectify faults of the previous government. I draw the honourable member's attention to the arms-length transaction changes. On coming into office in 1983, the government said, `Look at these terrible private superannuation funds. Those people in private enterprise are a bunch of cheats. They set up a superannuation fund. They borrow from it and they plough it back into the business. That is a terrible thing to do.' The government wiped that out. Today, it is again instigating that process because it was mistaken, wrong and stupid in its assessment. The government could have moved to the point of a non-arms-length relationship. But it refused to listen to the opposition. It said, `All private enterprise is bad. Employers are a bunch of rip-off merchants.'
Mr Robert Brown interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on. The honourable member should read back through the speeches of Hurford and others in the parliament about private enterprise superannuation funds. He was in the House. He was interested and he did nothing to moderate the attitude of the government, which went completely on the wrong swing.

PARA.TAB: Instead of making changes that would have pulled out the cherry picking processes—and I said at the time that the government should have done that—the government went right past it and wiped out every opportunity for reinvestment. The arms-length transactions that are being proposed here so that there should be no advantage in a non-arms-length transaction which cannot be obtained in an arm's length transaction is a sensible provision. I applaud this change but the government has wasted over 10 years of possible investment in Australia by allowing private enterprise to use the capital it was accumulating.

The government has failed in this area because it has no strategy for national savings of any sort. The savings program in Australia has worked because we have got one of the lowest savings ratios of any nation on earth, and the government has encouraged that by the policies it has created. The government's national economic policies, with high inflation and high interest rates, have discouraged people from any concept of saving. It is too risky for the average householder to save other than by putting funds into bricks and mortar.

The member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) realises that when the government runs a high inflation and high interest regime people feel an uncertainty. People put faith only in what they can grab at the moment. To invest in the long-term bond or share market is unattractive. People have seen what has happened with the manipulation by the so-called high fliers of the 1980s. That sort of investment is unattractive to most Australians. They do not understand it, it seems too risky and they are afraid of losing assets they have created, because of some person manipulating the system.

Superannuation is a slow and steady way of making savings, but there have been many confusing changes to this whole process and small yields for many people in the government's regime. Initially people started to be attracted to this but at this point in our history people are moving away from superannuation in their savings regimes. People have tended to invest in bricks and mortar and traditional investments.

The government has not applied its mind to the process of savings in Australia. It is presenting this superannuation change as the single plank of savings policy. It cannot do that. There must be a multiplicity of opportunities for people to invest in Australia, or in Australian institutions. The government has rightly said, `We need to have a savings policy.' What the government then does is go out on the market and borrow those Australian savings to fund its own mismanagement of the Australian economy. Under those circumstances, where does private enterprise then go to borrow money for advancement and development? It goes offshore and people wonder why we have got a foreign debt.

The government has created that by running a high deficit and by borrowing on the local market. The cost of money to the government does not matter. High interest rates do not really matter to the government. Borrowing overseas has not contributed in any great extent to the foreign debt but the government has forced others to do that by the regime it has run.

There is no attempt to address the problem of the national savings policy. We must have a policy and incentive must be provided for people to save. This is the big stick way of providing savings. Hand this big stick over to employers and say, `Put that money in.' There should be a change in ethos and attitude, and an encouragement for the average mum and dad—or young couple or person preparing for marriage or for a working life—who want to save to enter into a regime that they personally control, not a compulsory thing that is applied by the boss and that they have no say in. There is no commitment in the present process. There is no understanding of the benefits of a long-term saving regime to a family or to an individual in the way in which the government has approached this.

The government is saying, `Aussies are too dumb to go into a savings program on their own. We won't provide incentives, so we'll make it a forced process.' It is an educative and encouragement role that needs to be provided. The government is not doing that. The coalition believes there should be a national savings program and we will be providing incentives for that to occur. It must be joint.

I am not decrying the government's efforts completely, but I think the government has used a very prescriptive, rigid approach. Ultimately, it will yield no commitment on the part of the individual who is supposed to be making the saving. Ultimately, for many of the people who are involved in the superannuation schemes that the government has put under the aegis of the union movement, there will be no yield when they reach retirement.

In relation to the specifics of the legislation, it is a sensible change to bring in the non-bank financial institutions which are defined under the various financial institutions acts or codes of New South Wales, Victoria and the rest of the states. It is sensible to allow non-bank financial institutions to offer approved guarantees that currently are offered only by approved banks and the Commonwealth, states or territories. This change broadens the prospects for non-bank financial institutions. The clause amends the definition to read `approved non-bank financial institutions'. These are bodies recognised under the various laws and comprise building societies and other groups such as that. I have no problem with that change.

The arms-length transactions should never have been removed. The proposition to put them back is a commonsense reaction to a stupid anti-business reaction in 1983-84. The government went too far with that and it is now acknowledging that with these changes. The government tarred everyone with the same brush and said, `You're all bad news.' It was the only area in the whole business that needed to be dealt with. The government fooled around with it for ages. Meanwhile, people were ripping off funds and buzzing off overseas, and Hurford would not take action. It was a cherry picking process and there was manipulation. So the government fiddled with that and then it went in with a sledgehammer, but it did not need to go to the extent that it did to rectify the obvious problems. The problems had been partially dealt with by the coalition when it was in government. The Labor government needed to go further and it did. I applaud the intention but the result is now having to be rectified 10 years later. What a waste of investment. What a waste of productivity. What a waste of opportunity the government has created by being overzealous in this area.

There are provisions in this legislation that deal with the options for control and management of standard employer-sponsored funds. The amendment is proposing the way in which boards and trusts will be made up and, as my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) has said, the criteria are now there to ensure that the interests of the members are looked after. I also applaud the government for that. But, again, it is probably three or four years too late.

When the government went on a wild kick and said, `We will let the unions into the super field,' the opposition advised against that. `It would be a great thing for the unions to have,' said the government, and it was. We had Norm Gallagher and all of these blokes out of Melbourne as trustees to funds. The government knew that was stupid, but it would not admit it at the time. Norm was a trustee of the building industry fund. I do not want to blacken people's names completely, but we did have people with almost criminal records responsible for the funds of workers. They had no interest in how well those funds were going for the workers, and it is a lot of hogwash to suggest that they did. The government now knows that, and it is admitting it with the changes that it is now making.

The government is admitting that it was a fraud to present Normie and all of the boys as being good, upright citizens capable of being trustees of complicated investment insurance funds, and capable of making decisions on behalf of their members. However, that was not the case. The government is now recognising that, and it is saying that people must be properly equipped and they must have a code of behaviour that takes into account the interests of their members and the interests of members of the funds. That is absolutely spot on. What a shame it is that the government would not admit at the time that there needed to be a code of conduct, and that there needed to be a proper process by which trustees of funds were selected to ensure they had the qualities that were needed to do the job.

I have mentioned the savings capacity of Australia and the importance of superannuation as a very important plank in the process of developing a savings policy. Previous speakers have mentioned the contribution of Dr Vince FitzGerald. Although the government has ignored that report, FitzGerald opened up something that could be looked at either by a parliamentary committee or through a more detailed and lengthy discussion in the parliament. If the government is serious about commissioning inquiries such as the FitzGerald report on national savings, it should have a process whereby it has a more open debate than it has been prepared to have on the general issue of savings. The FitzGerald report was a good starting point, but the government found much of it unacceptable, and simply ditched it, leaving it to gather dust on the shelves. That is a shame, because it could have been a start of a changed regime.

The government is a bit precious in the way in which it behaves. This stems from the character of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating): any opinion which is slightly at variance with his own views must be wrong and is not accepted. Two years later, he might come back to it, knowing that it is right, but he is not sufficiently confident of his own ability to take advice, pick it up and turn it into something good. I believe that is what happened with the FitzGerald report. Anything that does not agree with the Prime Minister's first impression is rejected—he says that it is wrong.

The government is currently investigating a goods and services tax—a broad based consumer tax—and here we see the hypocrisy of government members, in the way that they behaved during the election campaign. They know very well that Treasury and its committees are now looking at a goods and services tax, or VAT, a value added broad based consumer tax. That is happening because the government does not know where it is going to get the dough from to run Australia. It has the hypocrisy to pick up something that it canned mercilessly and endlessly for 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is silence.
—They are not denying it. Of course, they cannot deny it. They know that we know.
—It was investigated in March of 1983 and that was sufficient for us.

—Let me tell you that you are back at it now. You know that you are back at it now. You are looking at a way in which you can collect extra funds and, therefore, a broad based consumer tax is being considered by the government.

PARA.TAB: That has been the problem with superannuation. Instead of building something constructive that we can both participate in, the government has refused to take advice. Although it has been obvious that we have some expertise and knowledge, the government has stuck to things that are untenable. In one instance, it has clung for 10 years to an attitude that was wrong and outdated, and now it has made a modification. It has lost by that process and Australia has been the poorer. What the government could have done—and should have done—was to listen to some of the expertise on our side and taken up our advice. But it had to prove how tough it was by rejecting that advice.

I am now making a plea for the government to consider more broadly a national saving policy. Why look at more taxes? Why continue the big debt regime just to make the Prime Minister look good? Why not rein that debt in, make fewer demands on the savings of Australians, and allow those savings to be put to productive use in the nation? That can be done by making slight modifications. The government does not have to give away all of its ideology, but it could make this nation much better by adopting a national savings policy that is workable. It could moderate its demand on funds by running a lower deficit than is now the case. That would be beneficial to all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Amendment Bill covers a variety of technical amendments. It includes matters relating to non-bank financial institutions and the tightening of rules in regard to disclosure of protected information and documents; amendments to allow the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to provide protected information to the new Superannuation Complaints Tribunal; and provision to allow exempt public sector schemes to come within the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal regime, if that is deemed appropriate. Those are just some of the major matters dealt with in this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I would like to take the opportunity today to comment on a number of superannuation issues that are relevant to some of these amendments. I also congratulate the government and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), who is here today, on taking the decision to include medical disputes within the ambit of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal.

I have had some experience in this area some time ago, just prior to the introduction of occupational superannuation, dealing with total and permanent benefit claims for injured workers who are members of company superannuation schemes. While dealing with those claims, something that stood out more than anything else was the gross inadequacy of existing processes to enable workers to challenge decisions that had been made with respect to their total and permanent disablement benefit claims by the insurers backing the funds.

In my experience, companies such as AMP were generally quite fair in the way that they dealt with these disablement benefit claims. National Mutual was not so bad, but some of the others were pretty horrendous. A person virtually had to be in a wheelchair and have a seeing eye dog before he or she would even be considered to be totally and permanently disabled. Many injured workers, therefore, who quite clearly were never going to work again had their claims rejected.

That is where they then ran into some problems because, in the circumstances they faced, the only option they had was to take legal proceedings to the Supreme Court or the county court to allege either breach of trust or breach of contract or both. Naturally enough, those proceedings were probably a fifty-fifty bet in terms of likelihood of success and of course required significant funds to finance them. Naturally, if the injured worker was unsuccessful, the case would lead to fairly substantial awards of costs against the injured worker on top of his or her own outlay with respect to costs to finance the case itself.

However, in jurisdictions such as workers compensation, for example, because of the large volume of claims and the structures associated with those jurisdictions, it was possible for injured workers to pursue claims disputing findings about whether or not they had sustained incapacitating injuries as a result of their employment, without undertaking serious financial risk.

These problems, in effect, made it virtually impossible for injured workers to pursue disablement benefit applications in the normal legal system. So if their claim was arbitrarily rejected by one of the less scrupulous insurers backing these particular disablement benefit structures in the trust deed, then there was virtually nothing they could do about it. As a result, many injured workers in that period, who had been under the impression that they were covered by these clauses in their superannuation trust deed, missed out.

On many occasions when I was a lawyer, I had the unpleasant duty of advising injured workers—often middle-aged, male, lower-skilled workers who had suffered injuries that would prevent them from ever working again in anything for which they were remotely suited—that, in spite of what they had been told by their employer when they signed on to the superannuation scheme and in spite of what was written in the booklet advertising the details of the superannuation scheme, the disablement benefit that they thought they would be entitled to was not going to be available to them.

I note that legal proceedings are currently under way in Victoria, seeking to establish a test case on this issue, with respect to both breach of trust and breach of contract. One of the great problems in pursuing these cases is the old breach of contract problem of privity of contract and the fact that if you are a third party to the contract then you cannot be sued on the basis of that contract. Of course, the insurer, who is effectively making the decision about whether the disablement benefit claim would be acceded to or not, is a third party to the contract. The case of Trident v. McNiece established that that principle did not apply in the workers compensation situation, but the matter of whether that will be extended to total and permanent disablement benefits is yet to be seen.

In concluding this point, I again congratulate the government for determining to include these issues within the ambit of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal and also to ensure that the decisions of the tribunal are only appealable on issues of law to the Federal Court. That will mean that, for the first time, workers in this country have an accessible process available to them to get proper independent judicial decisions about disputes with respect to superannuation matters, be they medical disputes about disablement claims or disputes relating to other issues. That is a major step forward. As somebody who has had some experience in dealing with these issues at first-hand, I can say quite clearly that there will be a lot of ordinary Australian workers who will benefit as a result of this decision.

The second issue I would like to refer to also relates to death and disablement benefits in superannuation schemes, and that is the definition of `dependant' in the regulations with respect to the application of death benefits in superannuation schemes. At the moment, we have an unfortunate situation in the case of same-sex couples. Even if an individual who is a member of a same-sex couple nominates his or her partner as the beneficiary in the event of death with respect to superannuation entitlements, in many circumstances that nomination is meaningless.

Even if the partner is quite clearly financially dependent upon the deceased partner, he or she is unable to get the death benefit payment from the superannuation fund. The reason is in the way that the death benefits regulations are structured. A `dependant' is defined on the basis of sexual relationship rather than on the basis of the actual nature of the relationship and whether there is financial or economic dependency there.

Most recently in Melbourne, we had a situation where there were two men who were partners living in an established long-term relationship. Both of them had AIDS, and one of them died. The surviving partner—in spite of the fact that he had been nominated by the deceased partner as the beneficiary in his occupational superannuation scheme in the event of his death—was unable to claim the death benefit; yet it was obvious that he, more than virtually anybody else, had a very clear financial need to claim that death benefit.

It is quite clear that we should not allow unrestricted choice on the part of members of superannuation schemes to nominate death beneficiaries, because there is a social purpose behind the death benefit structure in superannuation schemes. It is designed to ensure that dependants of deceased beneficiaries of superannuation schemes are not left in sudden and extreme poverty, and that there is at least some payment to allow them to overcome the economic loss arising from the death of the beneficiary. I would argue that we should make that definition non-discriminatory. We should focus not on the sexual nature of the relationship between the dependants, but simply on the nature of the economic or financial relationship and the potential consequence of death for that dependence. Therefore we should have a non-discriminatory definition.

I note also that there are proceedings currently in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which will test whether my interpretation of the existing definition in the regulations is correct, and it may well be that any changes to the regulations may be unnecessary if the AAT hands down a finding that the existing definition is in fact wide enough to encompass same-sex relationships.

I would now like to move on to the broader question of the general structure of superannuation in this country. In some respects, I—like the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman)—do not think that the existing situation is perfect, but I come to this question from a slightly different perspective, that of somebody who is still basically a supporter of the 1975 Hancock report and the concept of a totally integrated national superannuation scheme.

The occupational superannuation structure that we have introduced under this government is essentially a compromise position from the rag-tag situation we had prior to 1983, when the majority of the population had no superannuation coverage. That majority was overwhelmingly the lower paid, particularly women. The structure that has been introduced is essentially a compromise which has had the benefit of extending superannuation to the vast bulk of the population, which is a major advance that cannot be questioned, in my view.

I was centrally involved, along with the former assistant secretary of the ACTU, Garry Weaven, in negotiating what I believe to be the first major common rule award provision with respect to occupational superannuation, which was to apply to large numbers of workers—union members and non-union members—in 1989. That provision was certainly a major step forward for members of my union and for lower paid workers, particularly women workers, who previously had had no superannuation and had been excluded from that.

However, it is worth noting that there is still a range of anomalies in the structure that we have at present. We need to address these anomalies in the long term. There is a clear gender bias because of the tendency for women, more so than men, to move in and out of the work force and, therefore, women's ability to accumulate superannuation entitlements is inevitably restricted.

Lower paid and particularly casual workers will also receive less than higher paid and full-time workers. The administration costs associated with administering a complex scheme of this nature, which varies from award to award and imposes those costs directly on businesses administering the scheme, must also be questioned. There are complexities associated with transferring membership of schemes and multiple membership. The problem of small sums has been addressed by the government, but it is still a complexity which exists because of the way in which the need to provide universal superannuation has been approached.

Occupational superannuation in effect functions as a small additional tax on employment, and that is clearly a matter of concern. The extent to which that causes problems has been grossly exaggerated by some people in the business community. Nonetheless it is still an issue. Personally, I believe it would be better if it were attached to the personal income taxation of individuals, rather than being equivalent to a payroll tax. There are also substantial compliance problems because of the nature of the structure of the scheme.

One of the major problems that we now have with the structure is that ultimately we have a de facto tax delivering billions of dollars not to the government, but to the large superannuation funds such as National Mutual and AMP, with very limited accountability on the part of the beneficiaries. Thus enormous economic power is being handed to organisations like AMP and National Mutual, with very limited accountability.

Those companies are starting to use that power in a more interventionist way, as in the case of the change of management at Goodman Fielder Ltd. Notionally, superannuation funds that were held on my behalf, and on behalf of hundreds of thousands of others, were at play in those sorts of decisions. Unlike taxation, where people can vote the government that is making those decisions on how to spend that money into or out of office, the ability to do so with respect to those large superannuation funds is far more limited.

In conclusion on that point, I fundamentally philosophically support a universal single superannuation scheme. I concede that the proposition in the Hancock report that there be a single fund with a single, in effect, public sector investment decision making process is probably not appropriate. It is probably not politically acceptable in this day and age. Therefore, if we were to move to a single universal scheme, we could do so on the basis of contracting out the investment process to a variety of players in the investment market.

Thus there would be a single fund, a single administration and a single collection of moneys. The process of investing those funds could be contracted out to, for example, AMP and National Mutual and the various other players in the game. They would then have to compete with each other on the basis of investment performance. That is an idea that needs to be pursued in the future.

My final comment relates to the introduction of employee contributions for occupational superannuation. The government is committed to it. I argue that we should consider doing at least the first stage of that in the very near future, if for no other reason than as a demand management tool. If we are to calm down the economic recovery that is now well under way and make sure that inflationary pressures and the current account problem do not get out of hand, then there are alternatives to interest rate increases.

The major alternative that we need to consider is the introduction of the first one per cent of that three per cent that we are committed to introducing by the year 2002-3. This would have a variety of benefits. Obviously, the optimum time to introduce these employee contributions would be when growth and employment are improving strongly, rather than when we are in recession. Although there would be a displacement effect to some degree with respect to saving, that would probably be less than half and therefore there would be a significant increase in national savings. The structural economic problem of inadequate savings would be addressed in a way that interest rate increases do not address.

The effective equity of introducing this levy of employer superannuation contributions would be much more than interest rate increases and it would be unlikely to flow through into higher wage claims in the same way as interest rate increases. It would have roughly the same macro-economic effect as a taxation increase. Aggregate savings would be increased, current disposable income would be reduced and this would dampen down aggregate demand. The final benefit of this type of approach would be that, unlike interest rate increases, it would not act as a disincentive to investment. The great problem with increasing interest rates, as we witnessed in 1988-89, is that ultimately it causes a crunch with business investment, whereas introducing the first stage of employee superannuation contributions would not do that. In fact, it would provide additional funds for investment, so it would have precisely the reverse effect.

I commend the government to consider introducing that first stage of the employee superannuation contribution at some stage in the first half of next year. I think it would be the optimum time to do so for reasons of macro-economic management. It is also something that is obviously critical to the ultimate achievement of a just and effective superannuation and retirement incomes policy for this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In particular, I thank the members of the government who have contributed to this debate. I note that the opposition members have made quite a wide ranging contribution as well. I think it is fair to say that many of the issues we covered strayed somewhat from the actual provisions that are contained in the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill. Nevertheless, these are important issues and it is worth while getting the range of views that come forward.

PARA.TAB: I notice the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) is still in the chamber. I want to touch on a couple of the issues he raised, given that he spent scarcely any time on the bill. He raised a series of issues that are in need of some response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was replying to your previous speaker.

—For 17 1/2 minutes he was, in fact, making observations about directing investments. At the ASFA conference yesterday, the Western Australian Minister for Finance opened the conference and chided all the delegates because they were not making enough investment in the resource industries of Western Australia, and the like. He also has responsibility for the TAB. He drew the parallel that superannuation funds should be looking not only at the TAB type of guarantee arrangements with investments but also at all those great opportunities in resource and entrepreneurial sectors, and so on.

PARA.TAB: It is all right for the Western Australian Minister for Finance to say that but, if one of our members makes similar sorts of observations, the world is supposed to fall in, according to the honourable member for Bradfield. The fact of the matter is that what the government has taken as a very conscious decision is an approach under SI(S) that directs the responsibility of the investment strategy onto the trustees to develop. It is a process that places legal obligations as part of that process. Aside from the direct prudential issues that are involved in that, the government has made it particularly clear in SI(S) that neither the government nor any other party has any role in the process beyond that. It is the direct responsibility of the trustees to formulate the investment strategy. The Treasurer made the point yesterday, at that conference. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The SI(S) legislation emphasises that primary responsibility for the prudent management of the fund rests with the trustees. It prohibits trustees from acting under instruction from outside parties. Naturally, the government welcomes the superannuation fund investments in areas such as emerging technologies, regional industries and infrastructure as part of a balanced investment portfolio. But the government has repeatedly said it will not force or mandate superannuation funds or trustees to invest in particular areas.

I reiterate that there is absolutely no intention on the government's part of changing this, and this SI(S) amendment package does nothing of the sort. In fact, it strengthens the provisions relating to the prudential regime and makes some variations in the light of the experience that we have had in recent times, but ensures that those fundamentals that apply under SI(S) in terms of trustee obligations on investment, and therefore their responsibility to fund members, are very much at the forefront in their legal obligations. Nothing is going to change that. It does not matter that we get comments of one sort or another, be they from the Western Australian Minister for Finance or someone else; those fundamentals will still be there. That is not to say that that diversified investment portfolio does not open up the options of picking up all the different possibilities as far as investment is concerned.

PARA.TAB: One other thing that was notable, given the member for Bradfield's comments about the government's approach to these issues, was that the president of ASFA made the point yesterday that ASFA was in fact formed because the Menzies government in 1961 was talking about taking steps to direct where superannuation funds were to go. They formed the association, which has now been going for 33 years, because of the Menzies government's proposals in relation to superannuation. So we see the sort of nonsense that is really behind that comment that the member for Bradfield made.

I make the point that the superannuation guarantee is a fundamental part of our national savings strategy. Superannuation savings today through the super guarantee represent $185 billion and by the year 2002, when the full transition process comes into effect, will represent $450 billion in contributions to national savings. And the opposition, for all its talk about national savings, still has in The Things That Matter document the fact that it is going to freeze the superannuation guarantee at its current level, a direct negative in terms of national savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —And encourage voluntary contributions.

—Yes. But, as the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) pointed out, a real decision was made in the area of industrial relations in the wage trade-off arrangements with the ACTU in the accord to ensure that employees made the contribution. Because of the forgone salary that they could have achieved, they have made those commitments to long-term savings through superannuation. So the fact is that the opposition's approach to freezing the superannuation guarantee would have a very negative effect on national savings, and that is not disputed by anybody in the industry. The industry itself is calling on the opposition to abandon that short-sighted policy that it had in Fightback and that it still has in The Things That Matter document. With those few words, I am pleased to commend the bill to the Main Committee and to recommend the second reading.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Elliott)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: MERIT PROTECTION (AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 19 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe The Hon N.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to make a number of amendments to the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act 1984. The Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act was one of the elements of the government's Public Service reform package in 1984. The act provided for the establishment of the Merit Protection and Review Agency, the MPRA, as an independent statutory authority responsible for handling grievances and appeals of public servants.

PARA.TAB: The government remains committed to the principles on which the MPRA was established and which are articulated in its legislation—fairness, equity, sound personnel management practices, efficiency and good staff relations. The government sees the MPRA having an important role in preserving key values in Australian government employment and in particular in preserving the merit system. In its first 10 years, the MPRA has developed an enviable reputation for probity and independence.

The amendments cover a range of matters designed to facilitate and improve the performance of the MPRA's functions and to further the objectives contained in the act. The most important amendment provides for the MPRA, or a committee established by it, to perform specified employment related functions in addition to those already provided for in the act.

This means that the MPRA or one of its committees could, for example, at the request of a Commonwealth department or authority and the principal relevant staff organisation, mediate in a dispute, select staff for transfer or, where there is a `spill' of positions, establish an order of merit for selection.

The amendments also provide for the MPRA to deem a promotion appeal to be an application for review and vice versa to help avoid situations where an officer with an otherwise valid entitlement may be disadvantaged because of his or her lack of detailed knowledge of the relevant legislation.

The MPRA will also have the power to issue guidelines to joint selection committees which are tripartite staff selection committees with a convenor nominated by the MPRA. There is generally no appeal against the outcome of a joint selection committee process, with resultant time and cost savings in comparison to standard methods of staff selection. The MPRA currently has the power to issue guidelines in relation to review committees.

To conclude, the remaining amendments are minor. They are designed to bring particular provisions into line with similar provisions already contained in the act. I present the explanatory memorandum for the bill and commend the bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hawker) adjourned.

PARA.TAB: Is the Australian Taxation Office able to report the proportion of income taxpayers in each OECD nation who complete their tax returns without professional assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The number of Australian individual taxpayers who completed their tax return without professional assistance in 1992-93 was 26 per cent.
The Australian Taxation Office is not able to provide statistics on taxpayers who complete their tax returns without professional assistance for other OECD nations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: Further to the answer to question No. 459 (Hansard, 13 December 1993, page 3889), following enactment of the Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No.3) 1992, what sums did banks claim between 1 July and 30 June 1993 as deductions under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 for cases in which (a) a portion of bad debt and (b) the total debt was written off.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Australian Taxation Office collects figures on bad debts claimed as a deduction against taxable income but cannot distinguish between partial and total write offs. Figures from taxation returns for the 1992-93 income year (1 July 1992 to 30 June 1993 or substituted accounting period) show that banks claimed deductions for bad debts totalling $1,696 million.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 19 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: Further to the answer to Question No. 1150 (Hansard, 27 June 1994, page 2029), what (a) was the nature of the training which the Kimberley Land Council has provided Aboriginal persons since 1990-91 and (b) were the funds provided under the Office of Labour Market Adjustment programs used for.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) The approvals under the TAP—Training for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders program involved on the job training in administrative/clerical skills in four individual placements. Over the same period two wage subsidy placements were also made under Jobstart.
